definition:
(1) To leave someone, especially someone you are responsible for.
Example: How could she abandon her own child? 
(2) To go away from a place, vehicle etc permanently, especially because the situation makes it impossible for you to stay.
Example: We had to abandon the car and walk the rest of the way. 
(3) To stop doing something because there are too many problems and it is impossible to continue.
Example: The game had to be abandoned due to bad weather. 
(4) To stop having a particular idea, belief, or attitude.
Example: They were accused of abandoning their socialist principles. 
(5) To feel an emotion so strongly that you let it control you completely.
Example: She abandoned herself to grief. 
(6) To leave a ship because it is sinking.
(7) If someone does something with abandon, they behave in a careless or uncontrolled way, without thinking or caring about what they are doing.
Example: They drank and smoked with reckless abandon. 
(8) To stop doing or using something because it is too difficult or unsuccessful.
Example: The company abandoned its takeover bid.
(9) If you abandon a ship or its cargo, you accept that it is too badly damaged to be saved, and so give it up to an insurance company in exchange for an insurance payment.
(10) To leave an organization because you believe that it is going to fail soon.
Example: The chairman and most of the board members had already abandoned ship.
(11) To no longer continue with a legal case etc.
Example: They decided to abandon their claim for damages.

(1) To become less strong or decrease.
Example: We waited for the storm to abate. 
(2) To become less strong or damaging, or to make something do this.
Example: The level of wage settlements has shown no signs of abating in recent months.

(1) Something that is abhorrent is completely unacceptable because it seems morally wrong.
Example: The practice of killing animals for food is utterly abhorrent to me.

(1) Used to say that someone dislikes someone or something very much.
Example: I cant abide that man  hes so self-satisfied. 
(2) To live somewhere.
(3) To accept and obey a decision, rule, agreement etc, even though you may not agree with it.
Example: You have to abide by the referees decision.

(1) The state of being able to do something.
Example: The ability to walk 
(2) Someone’s level of skill at doing something.
Example: The test measures your mathematical ability. 
(3) As well as you can.
Example: He completed the job to the best of his ability. 
(4) Makes nouns from adjectives ending in -able and -ible.
Example: Manageability

(1) Someone’s home – sometimes used humorously.
Example: Welcome to my humble abode. 
(2) The right to live in a country.
(3) The past tense of abide.
(4) The place where someone lives.
Example: He has the right of abode in the uk (= he has the right to live there ) .

(1) To officially end a law, system etc, especially one that has existed for a long time.
Example: Slavery was abolished in the us in the 19th century.  19 
(2) To officially end a law, a system for doing something, an organization etc, especially one that has existed for a long time.
Example: Inheritance tax in bulgaria was abolished in 2005.

(1) To exist in very large numbers.
Example: Rumours abound as to the reasons for his resignation. 
(2) If a place, situation etc abounds with things of a particular type, it contains a very large number of them.
Example: The forests abound with deer, birds, and squirrels.

(1) Not at work, school, a meeting etc, because you are sick or decide not to go.
Example: Students who are regularly absent from school 
(2) If someone or something is absent, they are missing or not in the place where they are expected to be.
Example: Plans to force absent fathers to pay child maintenance 
(3) A look etc that is absent shows you are not paying attention to or thinking about what is happening.
Example: The dull, absent look on her face implied boredom. 
(4) To not go to a place or take part in an event where people expect you to be.

(1) Regular absence from work or school without a good reason.
(2) The problem of employees not being at work when they should be.
Example: The company has a high rate of absenteeism.

(1) Complete or total.
Example: I have absolute confidence in her. 
(2) Used to emphasize your opinion about something or someone.
Example: Some of the stuff on tv is absolute rubbish. 
(3) Definite and not likely to change.
Example: We need absolute proof that he took the money. 
(4) Not restricted or limited.
Example: An absolute monarch 
(5) True, correct, and not changing in any situation.
Example: You have an absolute right to refuse medical treatment. 
(6) Measured by itself, not in comparison with other things.
Example: In absolute terms wages have risen, but not in comparison with the cost of living. 
(7) Something that is considered to be true or right in all situations.
Example: She believed in the importance of moral absolutes.

(1) To take in liquid, gas, or another substance from the surface or space around something.
Example: Plants absorb nutrients from the soil. 
(2) To read or hear a large amount of new information and understand it.
Example: Her capacity to absorb information is amazing. 
(3) To interest someone so much that they do not pay attention to other things.
Example: The movement and noise of the machines absorbed him completely. 
(4) To become part of something larger.
Example: California absorbs many of the legal immigrants to the us. 
(5) If something absorbs light, heat, energy, or noise, it takes it in.
Example: Darker surfaces absorb heat. 
(6) If something absorbs changes or costs, it accepts them and deals with them successfully.
Example: The beer industry had absorbed a doubling of federal tax in 1991. 1991 
(7) If something absorbs money, time etc, it uses a lot of it.
Example: Defence spending absorbs almost 20% of the countrys wealth.  20% 
(8) To reduce the effect of a sudden violent movement.
Example: A well-designed sports shoe should absorb the impact on your feet. 
(9) If a large organization absorbs a smaller one, it takes control of it and makes it part of the organization.
Example: The company was absorbed by ibm in 1995.
(10) If a business absorbs costs, it is able to deal with them without any bad effects.
Example: Careful cost control has allowed the bank to absorb the costs of the merger.
(11) If a market absorbs a product, it accepts it and is able to sell it.
Example: Canada absorbs about 23% of us exports.
(12) If something absorbs money or time, it uses a lot of it.
Example: Defence spending absorbs almost 20% of the countrys wealth.

(1) Based on general ideas or principles rather than specific examples or real events.
Example: The ability to translate abstract ideas into words 
(2) Existing only as an idea or quality rather than as something real that you can see or touch.
Example: The abstract nature of beauty 
(3) Abstract paintings, designs etc consist of shapes and patterns that do not look like real people or things.
(4) A painting, design etc which contains shapes or images that do not look like real things or people.
(5) A short written statement containing only the most important ideas in a speech, article etc.
(6) Considered in a general way rather than being based on specific details and examples.
Example: Talking about crime in the abstract just isnt enough. 
(7) To write a document containing the most important ideas or points from a speech, article etc.
(8) To remove something from somewhere.
(9) A short written statement that contains the most important details of a longer piece of writing such as a newspaper article, a report, or a speech.
Example: An abstract of the chairmans speech to the shareholders

(1) A general idea about a type of situation, thing, or person rather than a specific example from real life.
Example: Hes always talking in abstractions. 
(2) When you do not notice what is happening around you because you are thinking carefully about something else.
Example: She rocked the baby gently, gazing in abstraction at the flickering fire. 
(3) The use of shapes and patterns that do not look like real things.

(1) Completely stupid or unreasonable.
Example: It seems quite absurd to expect anyone to drive for 3 hours just for a 20-minute meeting.  3  20 
(2) Something that is completely stupid and unreasonable.
Example: Some of the stories he tells verge on the absurd. 
(3) A style of play for the theatre that was developed in the 1950s by writers such as samuel beckett and eugène ionesco, whose work expresses the belief that there is no god, and that human existence has no meaning or purpose. these plays are very different from traditional theatre. the characters do not communicate effectively with each other, and often their words do not make sense. beckett’s play waiting for godot is the best-known example of this type of theatre..

(1) A large quantity of something.
Example: An abundance of wavy red hair

(1) Cruel or violent treatment of someone.
Example: Several cases of child abuse 
(2) The use of something in a way that it should not be used.
Example: Government officials abuse of power 
(3) Rude or offensive things that someone says when they are angry.
Example: Vandalism and verbal abuse directed at old people 
(4) To treat someone in a cruel and violent way, often sexually.
Example: She was sexually abused as a child. 
(5) To deliberately use something for the wrong purpose or for your own advantage.
Example: Williams abused his position as mayor to give jobs to his friends. 
(6) To say rude or offensive things to someone.
Example: Many soldiers in belfast are verbally abused . 
(7) To treat something so badly that you start to destroy it.
Example: James abused his body for years with heroin and cocaine.

(1) Relating to education, especially at college or university level.
Example: He possessed no academic qualifications. 
(2) Concerned with studying from books, as opposed to practical work.
Example: The study of art as an academic discipline 
(3) Good at studying.
Example: Hes not very academic. 
(4) If a discussion about something is academic, it is a waste of time because the speakers cannot change the existing situation.
Example: The question of where we go on holiday is purely academic since we dont have any money. 
(5) A teacher in a college or university.

(1) If a process accelerates or if something accelerates it, it happens faster than usual or sooner than you expect.
Example: Measures to accelerate the rate of economic growth 
(2) If a vehicle or someone who is driving it accelerates, it starts to go faster.
Example: The car accelerated smoothly away. 
(3) To happen more quickly, or make something happen more quickly.
Example: Economic growth should accelerate as the year goes on.
(4) When the economy accelerates, demand for goods increases.
Example: The president will strive to keep the economy accelerating as the election nears.
(5) To agree that a debt should be repaid more quickly, either because the borrower and lender both want this, or because the borrower has failed to make necessary payments and the lender has the right to demand full repayment.
Example: If you get behind on your house payments, the creditor may call the loan in default, accelerate the debt , and begin foreclosure proceedings.

(1) Good enough to be used for a particular purpose or to be considered satisfactory.
Example: An agreement which is acceptable to all sides 
(2) Acceptable behaviour is considered to be morally or socially good enough.
Example: Alcohol is not an acceptable way out of your problems.

(1) The right to enter a place, use something, see someone etc.
Example: Access to the papers is restricted to senior management. 
(2) How easy or difficult it is for people to enter a public building, to reach a place, or talk to someone.
Example: Were trying to improve access for disabled visitors. 
(3) The way you use to enter a building or reach a place.
Example: Access is by means of a small door on the right. 
(4) To have a car, a computer etc that you can use.
(5) The legal right to see and spend time with your children, a prisoner, an official etc.
Example: My ex-husband has access to the children once a week. 
(6) To succeed in entering a place or in seeing someone or something.
Example: The police managed to gain access through an upstairs window. 
(7) To find information, especially on a computer.
Example: Users can access their voice mail remotely. 
(8) A former type of credit card in the uk which is now known as mastercard.
(9) The right to sell goods to a particular market or country without breaking any laws or agreements.
Example: Japan agreed to allow foreign manufacturers of satellite equipment equal access to the japanese market.
(10) The way in which you are able to find information held on a computer.
Example: In order to simplify access to the data, the computer program enables users to specify their own requirements.
(11) When you are allowed to see official documents.
Example: The national union of teachers has proposed that parents should have access to their childrens files.
(12) The ability to buy a product or make use of a service.
Example: The move is intended to widen the access to credit.
(13) The right to remove money from where it is invested in order to use it.
Example: Policyholders often feel more confident if they have access to their funds.
(14) To find information, especially on a computer.
Example: The software enables each client to access data from other databases.
(15) To be able to use something.
Example: Many customers now access their accounts using the internet.

(1) A place, building, or object that is accessible is easy to reach or get into.
Example: The island is only accessible by boat. 
(2) Easy to obtain or use.
Example: The need for a health service that is accessible to all 
(3) Someone who is accessible is easy to meet and talk to, even if they are very important or powerful.
Example: I think that youll find shes very accessible. 
(4) A book, poem, painting etc that is accessible is easy to understand and enjoy.
Example: He wants his music to be accessible to everyone.

(1) Something such as a piece of equipment or a decoration that is not necessary, but that makes a machine, car, room etc more useful or more attractive.
Example: Bathroom accessories such as mirrors and towel-rails 
(2) Something such as a bag, belt, or jewellery that you wear or carry because it is attractive.
Example: Fashion accessories 
(3) Someone who helps a criminal, especially by helping them hide from the police.
Example: An accessory to murder 
(4) Something that you add to a machine, tool, car etc so that it can do other things or in order to make it look attractive.
Example: They sell software and computer accessories.
(5) Small things that are used for a particular activity.
Example: A retail chain that sells cooking items, kitchen accessories and home furnishings
(6) Someone who helps a criminal, but is not directly involved in a crime.
Example: He was an accessory to murder.

(1) To praise someone or something publicly.
Example: His work was acclaimed by art critics. 
(2) Praise for a person or their achievements.
Example: The young singer is enjoying critical acclaim (= praise by people who are paid to give their opinion on art, music etc ) .

(1) A place for someone to stay, live, or work.
Example: The price for the holiday includes flights and accommodation. 
(2) An agreement between people or groups who have different views or opinions, that satisfies everyone.
Example: We reached an accommodation between both parties.

(1) To go somewhere with someone.
Example: Children under 14 must be accompanied by an adult. 14 
(2) To play a musical instrument while someone sings a song or plays the main tune.
Example: Daniel wanted liz to accompany him on violin. 
(3) To happen or exist at the same time as something else.
Example: The disease is accompanied by sneezing and fever. 
(4) If a book, document etc accompanies something, it comes with it.
Example: Please see accompanying booklet for instructions.

(1) To succeed in doing something, especially after trying very hard.
Example: We have accomplished all we set out to do.

(1) A written or spoken description that says what happens in an event or process.
Example: He was too shocked to give an account of what had happened. 
(2) An arrangement in which a bank keeps your money safe so that you can pay more in or take money out.
Example: My salary is paid into my bank account. 
(3) To consider or include particular facts or details when making a decision or judgment about something.
Example: These figures do not take account of changes in the rate of inflation. 
(4) Because of something else, especially a problem or difficulty.
Example: She was told to wear flat shoes, on account of her back problem. 
(5) An exact record of the money that a company has received and the money it has spent.
Example: The accounts for last year showed a profit of $2 million.  200 
(6) If you buy goods on account, you take them away with you and pay for them later.
(7) An arrangement that you have with a shop or company, which allows you to buy goods or use a service now and pay for them later.
Example: Can you charge this to my account please? 
(8) A statement that shows how much money you owe for things you have bought from a shop.
Example: James left the restaurant, settling his account by credit card. 
(9) An arrangement to sell goods and services to another company over a period of time.
Example: Our sales manager has secured several big accounts recently. 
(10) According to what a lot of people say.
Example: It has, from all accounts, been a successful marriage. 
(11) If you do something on someone’s account, you do it because you think they want you to.
Example: Please dont change your plans on my account. 
(12) By yourself or for yourself.
Example: Carrie decided to do a little research on her own account. 
(13) Used when saying that someone must not, for any reason, do something.
Example: On no account must you disturb me. 
(14) According to what you have said, especially when you have admitted doing something wrong.
Example: Bentley was, by his own account, over-sensitive to criticism. 
(15) Concerning a particular situation.
Example: There neednt be any more worries on that account. 
(16) To do something or perform very well or very badly.
Example: Kevin gave a good account of himself in todays game. 
(17) To force someone who is responsible for a mistake or a crime to explain publicly why they did it and punish them for it if necessary.
Example: The people responsible for the accident have never been brought to account. 
(18) To use something for a good purpose.
Example: Perhaps she could put some of her talents to good account by helping us. 
(19) Not important.
Example: As she grew up, her father was of no account to her. 
(20) To form a particular amount or part of something.
Example: Afro-americans account for 12% of the us population.  12% 
(21) To form a particular amount or part of something.
Example: Afro-americans account for 12% of the us population.  12% 
(22) To be the reason why something happens.
Example: Recent pressure at work may account for his behavior. 
(23) To give a satisfactory explanation of why something has happened or why you did something.
Example: Can you account for your movements on that night? 
(24) To say where all the members of a group of people or things are, especially because you are worried that some of them may be lost.
Example: Three days after the earthquake, more than 150 people had still to be accounted for.  3  150 
(25) An arrangement between a bank and a customer that allows the customer to pay in and take out money; bank account.
Example: She used her first pay check to open an account (= to start one ) .
(26) Words written on a cheque to show that the account to which it relates has been closed.
(27) A record showing a particular part of the finances of a business.
(28) The complete set of records showing money coming into and going out of a business, its profits, and its financial situation.
Example: The new accounts contain more bad news for shareholders.
(29) The department of a company that deals with its accounts.
Example: She works in accounts.
(30) An arrangement between a buyer and a seller for payment to be made some time after the buyer receives the goods or services.
Example: No interest is charged provided the account is settled (= the money owed is paid ) in full every month.
(31) Paid as part of the total amount that needs to be paid.
Example: Well pay you half of your fee on account.
(32) To be paid for later.
Example: Most of this equipment was bought on account.
(33) An organization that is a regular client of a company, especially an advertising agency.
Example: The agency won several major accounts this year.

(1) The profession or work of keeping or checking financial accounts, calculating taxes etc.
(2) The profession or work done by accountants in keeping the financial records of organizations and in giving advice to clients on tax and other financial matters.
Example: She did a one-year accountancy course.

(1) Someone whose job is to keep and check financial accounts, calculate taxes etc.
(2) A professional person whose job is to keep and check the financial records of an organization, or to advise clients on tax and other financial matters.
Example: People setting up in business on their own really need to employ an accountant.

(1) To gradually get more and more money, possessions, knowledge etc over a period of time.
Example: It is unjust that a privileged few should continue to accumulate wealth. 
(2) To gradually increase in numbers or amount until there is a large quantity in one place.
Example: Fat tends to accumulate around the hips and thighs. 
(3) To get, earn, or obtain something gradually over a period of time.
Example: He had accumulated $20,000 in interest.
(4) To increase or develop gradually over a period of time.
Example: The funds that had accumulated in their accounts

(1) The ability to do something in an exact way without making a mistake.
Example: He passes the ball with unerring accuracy. 
(2) The quality of being correct or true.
Example: Worries about the accuracy of government statistics

(1) Correct and true in every detail.
Example: The brochure tries to give a fair and accurate description of each hotel. 
(2) Measured or calculated correctly.
Example: It is difficult to get accurate figures on population numbers. 
(3) A machine that is accurate is able to do something in an exact way without making a mistake.
Example: The cutter is accurate to within  a millimetre.  1 / 2 
(4) An accurate shot, throw etc succeeds in hitting or reaching the thing that it is intended to hit.
Example: An accurate shot

(1) To make yourself or another person become used to a situation or place.
Example: It took a while for me to accustom myself to all the new rules and regulations.

(1) Something important that you succeed in doing by your own efforts.
Example: We try to celebrate the achievements of our students. 
(2) When you achieve something or when people achieve something.
Example: Roberts is researching the effect of social class on educational achievement.

(1) A chemical substance that has a ph of less than 7. strong acids can burn holes in material or damage your skin.
Example: Sulphuric acid 
(2) The drug lsd.
(3) Having a sharp sour taste.
Example: A juicy apple with a slightly acid flavour 
(4) An acid remark uses humour in an unkind way to criticize someone.
Example: I was expecting another of his acid remarks, but he remained silent. 
(5) A way of finding out whether something is as good as people say it is, whether it works, or whether it is true.
Example: People ask if the team is good enough. this match will be the acid test. 
(6) An acid soil does not contain much lime1(3).
Example: Blueberry bushes need a very acid soil.

(1) To admit or accept that something is true or that a situation exists.
Example: The family acknowledge the need for change. 
(2) If people acknowledge something, they recognize how good or important it is.
Example: N the brazilian coach acknowledged the talent of his players.
(3) To accept that someone or something has authority over people.
Example: Both defendants refused to acknowledge the authority of the court. 
(4) To publicly announce that you are grateful for the help that someone has given you.
Example: We wish to acknowledge the support of the university. 
(5) To show someone that you have noticed them or heard what they have said.
Example: Tom acknowledged her presence by a brief glance. 
(6) To let someone know that you have received something from them.
Example: I would be grateful if you would acknowledge receipt of this letter. 
(7) To tell someone that you have received something such as a letter they have sent to you.
Example: We shall be grateful if you will kindly acknowledge receipt of this letter.
(8) To admit or accept that something is true or exists.
Example: The government acknowledged that there had been irregularities at a number of voting centres.

(1) Relating to sound and the way people hear things.
(2) An acoustic guitar or other musical instrument does not have its sound made louder electronically.

(1) To deliberately find out about something.
Example: I need to acquaint myself with the new regulations. 
(2) To give someone information about something.
Example: You need to acquaint the police with the facts.

(1) Someone you know, but who is not a close friend.
Example: She was a casual acquaintance of my family in vienna. 
(2) A relationship with someone you know, but who is not a close friend.
Example: They developed an acquaintance over the internet. 
(3) To meet someone for the first time.
Example: I should be delighted to make mrs mcgoughs acquaintance. 
(4) Knowledge or experience of a particular subject.
Example: The practice of a lawyer requires acquaintance with court procedures. 
(5) A person of your acquaintance is someone that you know.
Example: The poems were written by various women of her acquaintance. 
(6) When you meet someone for the first time.
Example: Most people are nicer than you think on first acquaintance.

(1) To obtain something by buying it or being given it.
Example: Manning hoped to acquire valuable works of art as cheaply as possible. 
(2) To get or gain something.
Example: The college acquired a reputation for very high standards. 
(3) To gain knowledge or learn a skill.
Example: He spent years acquiring his skills as a surgeon. 
(4) To begin to like something.
Example: She had acquired a taste for european beer. 
(5) Something that people only begin to like after they have tried it a few times.
(6) To buy a company.
Example: The group wants to acquire the company for $18 a share.
(7) To buy part of a company.
Example: It has acquired a 50% stake in a french electronics retailer.
(8) To get something, especially something important or valuable.
Example: The course makes it possible for workers to acquire new skills.

(1) The process by which you gain knowledge or learn a skill.
Example: The acquisition of language 
(2) The act of getting land, power, money etc.
Example: The acquisition of new sites for development 
(3) Something that you have obtained by buying it or being given it.
Example: The art society is holding an exhibition of recent acquisitions. 
(4) When one company buys another one, or part of another one.
Example: The groups acquisition of 85 stores in california
(5) A company or part of a company that is bought by another company.
Example: The groups latest acquisition is a sportswear firm.
(1) Someone who entertains people by doing difficult physical actions such as walking on their hands or balancing on a high rope, especially at a circus.

(1) Acrobatic movements involve moving your body in a very skilful way, for example by jumping through the air or balancing on a rope.
Example: They performed some amazing acrobatic feats.

(1) To make an electrical system or chemical process start working.
Example: Cooking fumes may activate the alarm.

(1) Used to emphasize that something is real or exact.
Example: Im not joking. those were his actual words. 
(2) Used to introduce the most important part of an event or activity.
Example: The programme starts at 8.00 but the actual film doesnt start until 8.30.  8  8

(1) The ability to think quickly and make good judgments.
Example: The firms success is largely due to brannons commercial acumen.

(1) A treatment for pain and disease that involves pushing special needles into parts of the body.
Example: The four main acupuncture points

(1) An acute problem is very serious.
Example: The housing shortage is more acute than first thought. 
(2) An acute feeling is very strong.
Example: Acute pain 
(3) An acute illness or disease quickly becomes very serious.
Example: Acute arthritis 
(4) Acute senses such as hearing, taste, touch etc are very good and sensitive.
Example: Young children have a particularly acute sense of smell. 
(5) Quick to notice and understand things.
Example: Simons vague manner concealed an acute mind. 
(6) An acute angle is less than 90°.
(7) An acute accent (=a mark used to show pronunciation) is a small mark written above a vowel. in ‘café’, the letter ‘e’ has an acute accent..

(1) To gradually change your behaviour and attitudes in order to be successful in a new situation.
Example: The children are finding it hard to adapt to the new school. 
(2) To change something to make it suitable for a different purpose.
Example: The car has been adapted to take unleaded gas. 
(3) If a book or play is adapted for film, television etc, it is changed so that it can be made into a film, television programme etc.
Example: Many children buy books after they have been adapted for television.

(1) A film or television programme that is based on a book or play.
Example: The bbc adaptation of the best-selling book 
(2) The process of changing something to make it suitable for a new situation.
Example: Adaptation to the environment

(1) Someone who is unable to stop taking drugs.
Example: A recovering heroin addict 
(2) Someone who is very interested in something and spends a lot of time doing it.
Example: My nephew is a complete video game addict.

(1) The need to take a harmful drug regularly, without being able to stop.
Example: Addiction to alcohol 
(2) A strong desire to do or have something regularly.

(1) Used to add another piece of information to what you have just said.
Example: The company provides cheap internet access. in addition, it makes shareware freely available.  
(2) The act of adding something to something else.
Example: The addition of networking facilities will greatly enhance the system. 
(3) Something that is added to something else, often in order to improve it.
Example: This excellent book will be a welcome addition to the library of any student. 
(4) The process of adding numbers or amounts to make a total.
(5) An extra room that is added to a building.
Example: They built a big addition onto the back of the house.

(1) More than what was agreed or expected.
Example: Additional information can be obtained from the centre.

(1) The details of the place where someone lives or works, which you use to send them letters etc.
Example: Whats your new address? 
(2) A formal speech that someone makes to a group of people.
Example: An address to the european parliament 
(3) The correct title or name that you should use when speaking or writing to someone.
(4) If you address an envelope, package etc, you write on it the name and address of the person you are sending it to.
Example: That letter was addressed to me. 
(5) If you address a problem, you start trying to solve it.
Example: Our products address the needs of real users. 
(6) To speak to someone directly.
Example: She turned to address the man on her left. 
(7) If you address remarks, complaints etc to someone, you say or write them directly to that person.
Example: You will have to address your comments to our head office. 
(8) To make a formal speech to a large group of people.
Example: He addressed an audience of 10,000 supporters. 
(9) To use a particular title or name when speaking or writing to someone.
Example: The president should be addressed as mr. president.     
(10) The number of the building and the name of the street and town etc where someone lives or works, especially when written on a letter or package.
Example: I wrote the wrong address on the envelope.
(11) To write on an envelope, package etc the name of the person you are sending it to.
Example: If you address the letter, ill mail it to you.

(1) To make a book, list, record etc, using different pieces of information, music etc.
Example: The document was compiled by the department of health 
(2) To put a set of instructions into a computer in a form that it can understand and use.
(3) To collect information together and write it into a list, report, book etc.
Example: Our staff are compiling the material for an on-line database.
(4) To put instructions into a computer in a form that the computer can understand and use.
Example: You do not have to exit the editor, compile the program, run the program, then reload the editor to fix any bugs.

(1) To say that you are annoyed, not satisfied, or unhappy about something or someone.
Example: Residents are complaining because traffic in the area has increased. 
(2) Used to say that a situation is satisfactory, even though there may be a few problems.
Example: I make a good living. i cant complain. 
(3) To say that you feel ill or have a pain in a part of your body.
Example: Dans been complaining of severe headaches.

(1) A statement in which someone complains about something.
Example: If you wish to make a complaint, you should see the manager. 
(2) Something that you complain about.
Example: Our main complaint was the poor standard of service. 
(3) An illness that affects a particular part of your body.
Example: He is having treatment for a chest complaint . 
(4) A written or spoken statement by someone complaining about something.
Example: Our sales assistants are trained to deal with customer complaints in a friendly manner.
(5) A statement made by a person bringing a case or making a claim in a court of law, stating the facts upon which the case or claim is based.
(6) A statement made by one person against another in a legal case, either in a court or to an officer of the court.
Example: The defence counsel pointed out that the complaint had not been served until 14 february this year.

(1) Complementary things go well together, although they are usually different.
Example: The computer and the human mind have different but complementary abilities. 
(2) Complementary colours of light are very different and combine to make white.
(3) Two angles that are complementary add up to 90 degrees.
(4) Sold or used with other products.
Example: Complementary goods, for example videocassettes and videorecorders

(1) Used to emphasize that a quality or situation is as great as it could possibly be.
Example: The police were in complete control of the situation. 
(2) Including all parts, details, facts etc and with nothing missing.
Example: A complete set of china 
(3) Finished.
Example: Work on the new building is nearly complete. 
(4) Having particular equipment or features.
Example: The house comes complete with swimming pool and sauna. 
(5) To finish doing or making something, especially when it has taken a long time.
Example: Students must complete the course. 
(6) To make something whole or perfect by adding what is missing.
Example: The childs task was to complete the sentences. 
(7) To write the information that is needed on a form.
Example: In all, more than 650 people completed the questionnaire.  650

(1) Consisting of many different parts and often difficult to understand.
Example: A complex system of highways 
(2) A complex word or sentence contains a main part and one or more other parts.
(3) A group of buildings, or a large building with many parts, used for a particular purpose.
Example: The town has one of the best leisure complexes in the country. 
(4) A large number of things which are closely related.
Example: China was a complex of different societies. 
(5) An emotional problem in which someone is unnecessarily anxious about something or thinks too much about something.
Example: I used to have a complex about my looks.

(1) The state of being complicated.
Example: There is increasing recognition of the complexity of the causes of poverty. 
(2) One of the many details or features of something that make it hard to understand or deal with.
Example: The complexities of economics are clearly explained.

(1) To make a problem or situation more difficult.
Example: The situation is complicated by the fact that ive got to work late on friday. 
(2) To make an illness worse.
Example: A heart condition complicated by pneumonia

(1) Difficult to understand or deal with, because many parts or details are involved.
Example: A complicated voting system 
(2) Consisting of many closely connected parts.
Example: A complicated pattern

(1) A remark that shows you admire someone or something.
Example: All the guests paid her extravagant compliments. 
(2) To be pleased about what someone says about you, even though they may not mean to be nice.
Example: They all seem to think that i ask rather cheeky questions, which ill take as a compliment. 
(3) An action that shows you admire someone.
Example: He paid maclennan the finest compliment of all by imitating him. 
(4) To try to make someone say something nice about you.
(5) Praise or good wishes.
Example: This soup is delicious; my compliments to the chef. 
(6) Used by a person or company when they send or give something to you.
Example: With the compliments of j. smith & son. 
(7) Used as a spoken or written greeting at christmas and new year.
(8) To behave towards someone in the same way as they have behaved towards you.
Example: They didnt take a lot of notice of me, and i returned the compliment. 
(9) Something that someone says to you which is nice and not nice at the same time.
Example: youve got a brain. try using it. thanks for the back-handed compliment!     
(10) To say something nice to someone in order to praise them.
Example: Bob complimented me on my new hairstyle.

(1) To do what you have to do or are asked to do.
Example: Failure to comply with the regulations will result in prosecution. 
(2) To obey a law or rule, or to keep an agreement.
Example: The high costs of upgrading aging mills to comply with environmental regulations

(1) One of several parts that together make up a whole machine, system etc.
Example: Companies that make electronic components for computer products 
(2) The component parts of something are the parts that it consists of.
Example: Weve been breaking down the budget into its component parts. 
(3) One part of something.
Example: Gas will continue to be a major component of the countrys energy supply mix.
(4) One part used in making a machine, vehicle etc.
Example: Auto components (= ones used in cars ) company

(1) To be formed from a number of substances, parts, or people.
Example: Water is composed of hydrogen and oxygen. 
(2) To write a piece of music.
Example: Barrington has composed the music for a new production of a midsummer nights dream. 
(3) To write a letter, poem etc, thinking very carefully about it as you write it.
Example: Compose a letter to your local paper stating your views on an issue of your choice. 
(4) To try hard to become calm after feeling very angry, upset, or excited.
Example: Lynn took several deep breaths to compose herself. 
(5) To arrange the parts of a painting, photograph, or scene in a way that achieves a particular result.
Example: I like the way he composes his photographs.

(1) The way in which something is made up of different parts, things, or members.
Example: The composition of the group that is studied depends on the interests of the researcher. 
(2) A piece of music, a poem, or a piece of writing.
Example: A composition by jazzman dave brubeck, called chromatic fantasy   
(3) The way in which the different parts that make up a photograph or picture are arranged.
Example: Martin starts by lightly sketching in the compositions for his paintings. 
(4) A short piece of writing about a particular subject, that is done at school.
Example: I had to write a composition about the royal visit. 
(5) The process of arranging words, pictures etc on a page before they are printed.
(6) An arrangement between a person or organization that owes money and the people or organizations the money is owed to concerning the way in which the debts should be repaid.
Example: The debtor may then make a composition with his creditors, but if this is not done he will be made bankrupt.

(1) A substance containing atoms from two or more elements.
Example: Man-made organic compounds 
(2) A combination of two or more parts, substances, or qualities.
Example: Teaching is a compound of several different skills. 
(3) An area that contains a group of buildings and is surrounded by a fence or wall.
Example: A prison compound 
(4) A noun, adjective etc that is made up of two or more words. the noun ‘flower shop’ and the adjective ‘self-made’ are compounds..
(5) To make a difficult situation worse by adding more problems.
Example: Helmuts problems were compounded by his lack of concentration. 
(6) To make a bad action worse by doing more bad things.
Example: He compounded the offence by calling his opponents liars. 
(7) To be a mixture of things.
Example: A smell compounded of dust and dead flowers 
(8) To pay interest that is calculated on both the sum of money and the interest.
Example: Interest is compounded quarterly. 
(9) A single eye, leaf etc that is made up of two or more parts.
(10) A noun, adjective etc that is made up of two or more words. for example, ‘ice cream’ is a compound noun..
(11) A sentence that has two or more main parts.
(12) To pay interest on both a sum of money and the interest already earned on it.
Example: My bank compounds interest quarterly.

(1) The ability to understand something.
Example: They dont have the least comprehension of what im trying to do. 
(2) An exercise given to students to test how well they understand written or spoken language.
Example: New methods of testing reading comprehension

(1) Including all the necessary facts, details, or problems that need to be dealt with.
Example: We offer our customers a comprehensive range of financial products. 
(2) Motor insurance that pays for damage whether it is caused by you or someone else.
(3) A system of education in britain in which children of different abilities go to the same school and are taught together.

(1) To press something or make it smaller so that it takes up less space, or to become smaller.
Example: Light silk is best for parachutes, as it compresses well and then expands rapidly. 
(2) To make a computer file smaller by using a special computer program, which makes the file easier to store or send, or to become smaller in this way.
Example: The program compresses any data saved to the disk. 
(3) To write or express something using fewer words.
Example: In this chapter we compress into summary form the main issues discussed so far. 
(4) To reduce the amount of time that it takes for something to happen or be done.
Example: Many couples want to compress their childbearing into a short space of time in their married life. 
(5) A small thick piece of material that you put on part of someone’s body to stop blood flowing out or to make it less painful.
Example: Apply a cold compress to the injury. 
(6) To make a computer file smaller, so that it takes up less space and is easier to store or send.
Example: Compressing data reduces storage and communication costs.

(1) To consist of particular parts, groups etc.
Example: The house comprises two bedrooms, a kitchen, and a living room. 
(2) To form part of a larger group of people or things.
Example: Women comprise a high proportion of part-time workers.

(1) An agreement that is achieved after everyone involved accepts less than what they wanted at first, or the act of making this agreement.
Example: Compromise is an inevitable part of marriage. 
(2) A solution to a problem in which two things or situations are changed slightly so that they can exist together.
Example: A happy compromise between the needs of family and work 
(3) To reach an agreement in which everyone involved accepts less than what they wanted at first.
Example: She admitted that she was unable to compromise. 
(4) To do something which is against your principles and which therefore seems dishonest or shameful.
Example: As soon as you compromise your principles you are lost. 
(5) An agreement between two people or groups in which both sides agree to accept less than they first asked for and to give up something that they value.
Example: Representatives of each side might well come to some sort of compromise .
(6) If two groups compromise, they each accept less than they first asked for, and each give up something that they value.
Example: The company has refused to compromise on a reduction in the working week.

(1) Something that is compulsory must be done because it is the law or because someone in authority orders you to.
Example: The threat of compulsory redundancies 
(2) Something that is compulsory must be done according to a law or rule.
Example: The company has introduced compulsory overtime for all its workers.

(1) To use a computer to control the way something is done, to store information etc.
Example: A scheme to computerize the library service 
(2) To use computers to control an operation, system, process etc.
Example: They computerized the accounts department back in 1985.

(1) To hide something carefully.
Example: The shadows concealed her as she crept up to the house. 
(2) To hide your real feelings or the truth.
Example: She tried to conceal the fact that she was pregnant.

(1) To admit that something is true or correct, although you wish it were not true.
Example: thats the only possible solution. yes, i suppose so,  charles conceded.      
(2) To admit that you are not going to win a game, argument, battle etc.
Example: The georgian forces defended the capital but were finally obliged to concede. 
(3) To not be able to stop your opponent from getting a goal etc during a game.
Example: The team has conceded only 19 goals in 28 games.  28  19 
(4) To give something to someone as a right or privilege, often unwillingly.
Example: The king finally agreed to concede further powers to parliament.

(1) To imagine a particular situation or to think about something in a particular way.
Example: Many people cant conceive of a dinner without meat or fish. 
(2) To think of a new idea, plan etc and develop it in your mind.
Example: Scientists first conceived the idea of the atomic bomb in the 1930s.  20  30 
(3) To become pregnant.
Example: Fertility treatment for women who have difficulty conceiving

(1) To think very carefully about something that you are doing.
Example: Now please concentrate. 
(2) To be present in large numbers or amounts somewhere, or to cause people or things to be present in large numbers or amounts somewhere.
Example: Italian industry is concentrated mainly in the north. 
(3) If something concentrates the mind, it makes you think very clearly.
Example: Relaxing in a jacuzzi concentrates the mind wonderfully. 
(4) To make a substance or liquid stronger by removing some of the water from it.
(5) To give most of your attention or effort to one thing.
Example: Doctors are aiming to concentrate more on prevention than cure. 
(6) A substance or liquid which has been made stronger by removing most of the water from it.
Example: Orange juice concentrate

(1) The ability to think about something carefully or for a long time.
Example: She needed all her powers of concentration to stop herself from slipping on the icy road. 
(2) A process in which you put a lot of attention, energy etc into a particular activity.
Example: Concentration on your health 
(3) A large amount of something in a particular place or among particular people.
Example: The concentration of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere 
(4) The amount of a substance contained in a liquid.
Example: Additives are expensive but are used in very low concentrations. 
(5) When companies combine to form larger companies, resulting in fewer businesses in an industry.
Example: Continental, in a move that underlines the growing concentration of the tire industry, announced the acquisition of a fiat tire subsidiary.

(1) An idea of how something is, or how something should be done.
Example: The concept of total patient care 
(2) An idea for a product.
Example: The management of an r&d process, from an original concept through to marketing, manufacture and end-use
(3) A rule or idea saying how something should be done.
(4) An economic idea stating that companies should make products which customers say they want, rather than products customers have to be persuaded to buy.
(5) An economic idea stating that companies should continuously try to improve their products because customers prefer to buy products with the best quality, features, and performance.
(6) An economic idea stating that companies should continuously try to manufacture and deliver their products without wasting time, money, or energy because customers want goods that are low in price and easy to obtain.
Example: The main objective of firms adhering to the production concept is to minimize costs, yet still maintain product quality.
(7) An economic idea stating that companies should try to sell the products they already have, rather than develop new products.

(1) An idea about what something is like, or a general understanding of something.
Example: The conception of parliamentary democracy 
(2) A process in which someone forms a plan or idea.
Example: The original conception of the book 
(3) The process by which a woman or female animal becomes pregnant, or the time when this happens.
Example: The moment of conception

(1) Dealing with ideas, or based on them.
Example: The conceptual framework of the play

(1) A feeling of worry about something important.
Example: The recent rise in crime is a matter of considerable public concern. 
(2) Something that is important to you or that involves you.
Example: His main concern is to be able to provide for his family. 
(3) A feeling of wanting someone to be happy and healthy.
Example: He was moved by her obvious concern. 
(4) If something is your concern, you are responsible for it.
Example: The money side of the business is your concern. 
(5) If something is not your concern, you are not interested in it and you do not need to worry about it or become involved in it.
Example: His affairs were none of her concern. 
(6) A business or company.
Example: The restaurant is a family concern. 
(7) If a story, book, report etc concerns someone or something, it is about them.
Example: This study concerns couples expectations of marriage. 
(8) To make someone feel worried or upset.
Example: Issues like food additives do concern me. 
(9) If an activity, situation, rule etc concerns you, it affects you or involves you.
Example: The tax changes will concern large corporations rather than small businesses. 
(10) To become involved in something because you are interested in it or because it worries you.
Example: He told them not to concern themselves about him. 
(11) An expression written at the beginning of a formal letter when you do not know the name of the person you want to communicate with.
(12) A business organization, usually a company.
Example: The french defense and electronics concern, matra sa

(1) A performance given by musicians or singers.
Example: A rock concert 
(2) People who do something in concert do it together after having agreed on it.
Example: Britain has to pursue policies in concert with other eu members.

(1) Something that you allow someone to have in order to end an argument or a disagreement.
Example: A policy of no concessions to terrorists 
(2) A special right that a particular person or group of people is allowed to have, for example by the government or an employer, or the act of giving or allowing something as a right.
Example: The ending of tax concessions for home owners 
(3) A reduction in the price of tickets, fees etc for certain groups of people, for example old people or children.
Example: To qualify for travel concessions you have to be 60.  60 
(4) A change in your behaviour that you make because of a particular situation or idea.
Example: He took off his jacket as a concession to the heat. 
(5) The right to have a business in a particular place, especially in a place owned by someone else.
Example: The company owns valuable logging and mining concessions. 
(6) The things sold at a concession stand.
(7) The right to carry out a particular business activity, given or sold to a company by a government or other public organization.
Example: Bellsouth paid b$2.65 billion for the concession to operate cellular phones in so paulo.
(8) A small shop in a hotel, theatre, office building etc owned and managed by another business.
Example: Snack concession sales per person at cinemas have increased.
(9) An agreement or rule allowing someone to pay less money, tax etc than they would normally pay.
Example: American express offered a rate concession to laura ashleys uk operations.
(10) The amount paid to an underwriter when new shares or bonds are made available for the first time.
Example: A public offering of 8 million common shares, priced at $16 a share through underwriters morgan stanley - selling concession is 61 cents

(1) To decide that something is true after considering all the information you have.
Example: The report concluded that the school should be closed immediately. 
(2) To complete something you have been doing, especially for a long time.
Example: When the investigation is concluded, the results will be sent to the us attorneys office. 
(3) To end something such as a meeting, book, event, or speech by doing or saying one final thing.
Example: Each chapter concludes with a short summary. 
(4) To finish arranging an agreement etc successfully.
Example: That same year, france concluded a trading agreement with spain. 
(5) To decide that something is true after considering all the facts.
Example: The stock exchange concluded that the accounts could be regarded as suspect because they made no reference to such businesses.
(6) To finish arranging an agreement, treaty, deal etc.
Example: We would like to conclude the deal by the end of the financial year.
(7) When something concludes, or you conclude it, it ends.
Example: By five the interview had at last concluded and we left.

(1) Something you decide after considering all the information you have.
Example: These are the reports main conclusions. 
(2) The end or final part of something.
Example: At the conclusion of the meeting, little progress had been made. 
(3) Used in a piece of writing or a speech to show that you are about to finish what you are saying.
Example: In conclusion, i would like to say how much i have enjoyed myself today. 
(4) The final arrangement of an agreement, a business deal etc.
Example: The conclusion of a peace treaty 
(5) To be certain to happen, even though it has not yet officially happened.
Example: The outcome of the battle was a foregone conclusion.

(1) Made of concrete.
Example: A concrete floor 
(2) Definite and specific.
Example: What does that mean in concrete terms ? 
(3) A substance used for building that is made by mixing sand, small stones, cement, and water.
(4) To cover something such as a path, wall etc with concrete.

(1) To agree with someone or have the same opinion as them.
Example: The committee largely concurred with these views. 
(2) To happen at the same time.
Example: Everything concurred to produce the desired effect.

(1) To say very strongly that you do not approve of something or someone, especially because you think it is morally wrong.
Example: Politicians were quick to condemn the bombing. 
(2) To give someone a severe punishment after deciding they are guilty of a crime.
Example: He was found guilty and condemned to death . 
(3) If a particular situation condemns someone to something, it forces them to live in an unpleasant way or to do something unpleasant.
Example: People condemned to a life of poverty 
(4) To state officially that something is not safe enough to be used.
Example: An old house that had been condemned

(1) Small drops of water that are formed when steam or warm air touches a cold surface.
Example: There was a lot of condensation on the windows. 
(2) When a gas becomes a liquid.
(3) The act of making something shorter.

(1) If a gas condenses, or is condensed, it becomes a liquid.
Example: The mist which condensed on every cold surface 
(2) To make something that is spoken or written shorter, by not giving as much detail or using fewer words to give the same information.
Example: This whole chapter could be condensed into a few paragraphs. 
(3) To make a liquid thicker by removing some of the water.
Example: Condensed soup

(1) The situation in which people live or work, especially the physical things that affect the quality of their lives.
Example: Conditions in the prison were atrocious. 
(2) The weather at a particular time, especially when you are considering how this affects people.
Example: The conditions during the first half of the match were appalling. 
(3) All the things that affect the way something happens.
Example: Under normal conditions, people will usually do what requires least effort. 
(4) The state that something is in, especially how good or bad its physical state is.
Example: The car has been well maintained and is in excellent condition. 
(5) How healthy or fit you are.
Example: She is being treated at walton hospital, where her condition is described as satisfactory.     
(6) Something that you must agree to in order for something to happen, especially when this is included in a contract.
Example: She laid down only one condition : that her name not be revealed.  : 
(7) Something that must exist or happen first, before something else can happen.
Example: Our goal is to create the conditions for a lasting peace. 
(8) An illness or health problem that affects you permanently or for a very long time.
Example: People suffering from this condition should not smoke. 
(9) The situation or state of a particular group of people, especially when they have problems and difficulties.
Example: The condition of the poor in our cities 
(10) Never.
Example: On no condition should untrained personnel use the equipment. 
(11) To make a person or an animal think or behave in a certain way by influencing or training them over a period of time.
Example: People are conditioned by society. 
(12) To control or decide the way in which something can happen or exist.
Example: What i buy is conditioned by the amount i earn. 
(13) To keep hair or skin healthy by putting a special liquid on it.
Example: A shampoo that washes and conditions all in one 
(14) Something stated in a contract, agreement, or insurance policy that must be done or must be true otherwise the contract, agreement, or policy will be ended or will not remain in force.
Example: You should read the conditions of your contract of employment carefully.

(1) A liquid that you put onto your hair after washing it to make it softer.
(2) A liquid that you wash clothes in to make them softer.

(1) To accept or forgive behaviour that most people think is morally wrong.
Example: I cannot condone the use of violence under any circumstances.

(1) To carry out a particular activity or process, especially in order to get information or prove facts.
Example: We are conducting a survey of consumer attitudes towards organic food. 
(2) To stand in front of a group of musicians or singers and direct their playing or singing.
Example: The orchestra is conducted by john williams.   
(3) To behave in a particular way, especially in a situation where people judge you by the way you behave.
Example: The players conducted themselves impeccably, both on and off the field. 
(4) If something conducts electricity or heat, it allows electricity or heat to travel along or through it.
Example: Aluminium, being a metal, readily conducts heat . 
(5) To take or lead someone somewhere.
Example: On arrival, i was conducted to the commandants office. 
(6) The way someone behaves, especially in public, in their job etc.
Example: The senators conduct is being investigated by the ethics committee. 
(7) The way in which an activity is organized and carried out.
Example: Complaints about the conduct of the elections 
(8) To manage or organize something.
Example: In future, mr o'reilly will conduct his business within the rules and regulations.
(9) To carry out an activity or process in order to obtain information or prove facts.
Example: The european parliament had asked its legal affairs committee to conduct an investigation into the case.
(10) To behave in a particular way, especially in a situation where other people judge your behaviour.
Example: Members of staff should conduct themselves in an appropriate manner when dealing with customers.
(11) The way in which a person behaves.
Example: It was claimed that the company had engaged in anti-competitive conduct.
(12) The way in which something is managed or organized.
Example: There has been a huge change in the conduct of monetary policy.

(1) Able to conduct electricity, heat etc.
Example: Copper is a very conductive metal.

(1) A large formal meeting where a lot of people discuss important matters such as business, politics, or science, especially for several days.
Example: Representatives from over 100 countries attended the international peace conference in geneva. 
(2) A private meeting for a few people to have formal discussions.
Example: After a brief conference with his aides, he left for the airport. 
(3) A group of teams that play against each other to see who is the best.
Example: The western conference finals 
(4) A large formal meeting, usually lasting a day or several days, where people discuss things in order to exchange information or to come to an agreement.
Example: A sales conference
(5) A private and formal meeting involving a small number of people.
Example: After a brief conference with ministers, the prime minister left for germany.

(1) The feeling that you can trust someone or something to be good, work well, or produce good results.
Example: Public confidence in the government is at an all-time low. 
(2) The belief that you have the ability to do things well or deal with situations successfully.
Example: I didnt have any confidence in myself. 
(3) The feeling that something is definite or true.
Example: How can anyone say with confidence that the recession is over? 
(4) If you tell someone something in confidence, you tell them something on the understanding that they will not tell anyone else.
Example: Ill tell you about moira  in confidence, of course. 
(5) To tell someone your secrets or private or personal details about your life.
Example: Elsa took me into her confidence and told me about some of the problems she was facing. 
(6) A secret or a piece of information that is private or personal.
Example: They spent their evenings drinking wine and sharing confidences. 
(7) The feeling that you can trust someone or something to do what they say, work properly etc.
Example: We have every confidence in the sales and marketing team.
(8) The feeling felt by businesses and investors that the economic situation will not become very bad.
Example: Economic confidence was raised further by trade deregulation and lower interest rates.

(1) The shape or arrangement of the parts of something.
Example: The configuration of pistons in an engine 
(2) The combination of equipment needed to run a computer system.

(1) To keep someone or something within the limits of a particular activity or subject.
Example: The police cadets duties were confined to taking statements from the crowd. 
(2) To keep someone in a place that they cannot leave, such as a prison.
Example: Any soldier who leaves his post will be confined to barracks (= made to stay in the barracks ) . 
(3) To stop something bad from spreading to another place.
Example: Firefighters managed to confine the fire to the living room. 
(4) If you are confined to a place, you have to stay in that place, especially because you are ill.
Example: Vaughan is confined to a wheelchair .

(1) To show that something is definitely true, especially by providing more proof.
Example: New evidence has confirmed the first witnesss story. 
(2) To say that something is definitely true.
Example: The president refused to confirm the rumor. 
(3) To tell someone that a possible arrangement, date, or situation is now definite or official.
Example: Could you confirm the dates we discussed? 
(4) To make you believe that your idea or feeling is right.
Example: This just confirms my worst fears. 
(5) To be made a full member of the christian church in a special ceremony.
(6) To say or show that something is definitely true.
Example: The company said the report confirmed what its own directors and accountants had already established.
(7) To tell someone that a possible arrangement, date, or time is now definite.
Example: Could you confirm the dates we discussed?

(1) A statement, document etc that says that something is definitely true.
Example: There has still been no official confirmation of the report. 
(2) A letter etc that tells you that an arrangement, date, time etc is now definite.
Example: Most hotels require confirmation from a prospective guest in writing. 
(3) A religious ceremony in which someone is made a full member of the christian church.

(1) A state of disagreement or argument between people, groups, countries etc.
Example: Conflicts over wage settlements 
(2) Fighting or a war.
Example: For years the region has been torn apart by armed conflicts. 
(3) A situation in which you have to choose between two or more opposite needs, influences etc.
Example: As women increasingly went out to work, the possibility of a conflict of loyalties became stronger. 
(4) A situation in which you have two opposite feelings about something.

(1) To disagree with something, especially by saying that the opposite is true.

(1) To break or to make something break, either so that it gets lines on its surface, or so that it breaks into pieces.

(1) An arrangement with a shop, bank etc that allows you to buy something and pay for it later.

Example: She already has two successful novels to her credit.

Example: There are no bank charges if you stay in credit.

Example: I dont have enough credits to graduate.

(12) To add money to a bank account.
Example: The cheque has been credited to your account. 
(13) To believe or admit that someone has a quality, or has done something good.
Example: Do credit me with a little intelligence! 
(14) If something is credited to someone or something, they have achieved it or are the reason for it.
Example: Much of manchester uniteds success can be credited to their manager. 
(15) To believe that something is true.
Example: We found his statement hard to credit. 
(16) An arrangement with a shop, supplier etc to buy something now and pay for it later.
Example: They are saving for new furniture - instead of buying on credit .
(17) An amount by which a payment is reduced, relating for example to goods you have returned.
Example: You can return the product within 30 days and get full credit toward the purchase of another.
(18) The right-hand side of each account in double-entry bookkeeping, the side used for increases in liabilities (=the amount of debt that must be paid) or revenues.
Example: Every time an entry is made on the debit side, another entry of equal value must be made on the credit side somewhere in the books.
(19) If you are in credit, you have money in your bank account; be in the black.
Example: There are no bank charges if you stay in credit.
(20) Another name for credit history.
Example: If your credit is good and you drive less than 15,000 miles a year, you should consider leasing your car rather than buying one.
(21) An arrangement with a bank for a loan, or bank lending in general.
Example: The company is to get an additional $225 million in credit with no strings attached.
(22) An amount of money given to you by the authorities, or an amount that you do not have to pay, which normally you would have to pay.
Example: The couple may claim a credit of $800 for child care against their tax bill.
(23) To add money to a bank account.
Example: The interest credited to the income account will be taxable.
(24) To make an entry on the credit side of an account in double-entry bookkeeping.

(1) To move in a quiet, careful way, especially to avoid attracting attention.

Example: He denied that giving civilian tasks to the nato forces was a case of mission creep.

(1) To refuse to consider someone’s idea, opinion etc, because you think it is not serious, true, or important.

(1) To refuse to do what someone with authority tells you to do, or refuse to obey a rule or law.
