(2) To put someone in a situation where they are not protected from something dangerous or unpleasant.
Example: The report revealed that workers had been exposed to high levels of radiation. 
(3) To show the truth about someone or something, especially when it is bad.
Example: The film exposes the utter horror of war. 
(4) To make it possible for someone to experience new ideas, ways of life etc.
Example: Some children are never exposed to classical music. 
(5) If a man exposes himself, he shows his sexual organs to someone he does not know in a public place, usually because he is mentally ill.
(6) To allow light onto a piece of film in a camera in order to take a photograph.
(7) To show other people feelings that you usually hide, especially when this is not planned.
Example: Im afraid i might expose my real feelings for him. 
(8) A story in a newspaper or on television that shows the truth about something, especially something dishonest or shocking.
Example: An expos of corrupt practices by lawyers 
(9) A newspaper article or a television programme which tells people the truth for the first time about something bad, or someone who has done something illegal, dishonest, or wrong.
Example: A sensational expos of insider dealing and corruption in the city
(10) To reveal the truth about someone or something that was hidden, especially when it involves something illegal, dishonest, or wrong.
Example: He achieved political prominence by exposing high-level corruption.
(11) To put goods in a place where people can see them or buy them.
Example: The products do not have to be exposed at the suppliers premises.

(1) When someone is in a situation where they are not protected from something dangerous or unpleasant.
Example: Prolonged exposure to the sun can cause skin cancer. 
(2) The action of showing the truth about someone or something, especially when it is bad.
Example: The exposure of his underground political activity 
(3) The attention that someone or something gets from newspapers, television etc.
Example: The failure of their marriage has got a lot of exposure recently. 
(4) The chance to experience new ideas, ways of life etc.
Example: The visit to germany gave them exposure to the language. 
(5) The harmful effects on your body of being outside in very cold weather without protection.
Example: We nearly died of exposure on the mountainside. 
(6) A length of film in a camera that is used to take a photograph.
Example: I have three exposures left on this roll. 
(7) The act of showing something that is usually hidden.
(8) The amount of financial risk that a company or person has.
(9) The direction in which a building, hill etc faces.
Example: My bedroom has a southern exposure. 
(10) Advertising and publicity which is used to sell a product or service.
Example: Our unrivalled advertising exposure gets fast results.
(11) When a newspaper article or a television programme tells people the truth for the first time about something bad, or someone who has done something illegal, dishonest, or wrong.
Example: Other exposures such as the irregular payments to graham roberts have come largely from the press or club officials.
(12) The amount of money that a bank lends to a customer, and which the bank therefore risks losing.
Example: Rising government debt will be a worry, though most of us will be concentrating on dealing with our own borrowing exposures .
(13) The amount of money an investor risks losing if their investments do badly, for example on the stockmarket.
Example: Some companies overlook the fact that foreign exchange exposures rise when the contract is signed.

(1) To tell or show what you are feeling or thinking by using words, looks, or actions.
Example: Bills not afraid to express his opinions. 
(2) To show or describe a particular feeling.
Example: Many of munchs paintings express a deep feeling of despair. 
(3) If something expresses itself, it becomes noticeable.
Example: Religious faith expresses itself in a variety of ways. 
(4) To change an amount or quantity into a different form, especially in mathematics.
Example: Express three-quarters as a decimal. 
(5) If a woman expresses milk, she presses milk out of her breast in order to feed it to her baby later.
(6) Deliberate and for a specific situation.
Example: The school was founded with the express purpose of teaching deaf children. 
(7) Clear and definite.
Example: He is not to leave without my express permission. 
(8) A train or bus that does not stop at many places and can therefore travel more quickly.
(9) A system that delivers letters and packages very quickly.
(10) Designed to help you move through a place more quickly.
Example: Express lanes on the freeway 
(11) A train or bus that does not stop in many places and therefore travels quickly.
(12) A post service that delivers letters and packages very quickly.
Example: Send these books by express. 
(13) To send or deliver a letter, package etc quickly using a special post service.
(14) A british daily tabloid newspaper which usually supports the ideas of the conservative party.
(15) To say what you think or feel about something.
Example: The sales manager expressed caution about the deal.
(16) To state clearly and openly something that has been agreed.
Example: Such warranties are implied, unless a contract expresses a contrary intention.
(17) To write a quantity or amount in numbers, letters, or other figures.
Example: The countrys level of expenditure is expressed as a percentage of the measure of economic activity.
(18) Stated or written clearly and openly, and showing a clear purpose or intention.
Example: The distinction between express authority and mere consent
(19) An express service is one that is quicker than the normal service.
Example: Overnight express trains

(1) To continue for a longer period of time, or to make something last longer.
Example: Management have agreed to extend the deadline. 
(2) To continue for a particular distance or over a particular area.
Example: The river nile extends as far south as lake victoria. 
(3) To make a room, building, road etc bigger or longer.
Example: We plan to extend the kitchen by six feet. 
(4) To affect or include people, things, or places.
Example: My duties at the school extend beyond just teaching. 
(5) To officially offer someone help, sympathy, thanks etc.
Example: Wed like to extend a warm welcome to our french visitors. 
(6) To stretch out a hand or leg.
Example: George extended his hand (= offered to shake hands ) . 
(7) To increase the number of points, games etc by which one person or team is ahead of other competitors.
Example: Manchester united extended their lead at the top of the table to 10 points.  10 
(8) If a table or ladder extends, it can be made longer.
(9) To increase the period of time for which an agreement, contract etc is effective.
Example: The company decided not to extend his employment contract.
(10) To make something bigger or increase its range.
Example: Conservationists have successfully blocked a plan to extend the golf course through the woods.
(11) To make credit available to someone.
Example: This was the first time that banks had extended credit to a mexican government agency.

(1) The process of making a road, building etc bigger or longer, or the part that is added.
Example: The extension of the jubilee underground line 
(2) Another room or rooms which are added to a building.
Example: The planned extension to the national museum 
(3) An additional period of time allowed for something.
Example: Donalds been given an extension to finish his thesis. 
(4) The development of something in order to make it affect more people, situations, areas than before.
Example: The extension of the copyright laws to cover online materials 
(5) One of many telephone lines connected to a central system in a large building, which all have different numbers.
Example: Can i have extension 316, please?  316 
(6) Used when you want to mention something that is naturally related to something else.
Example: My primary responsibility is to the pupils, and by extension to the teachers and parents. 
(7) Long pieces of artificial hair that can be attached to your hair to make it look longer.
(8) A set of three letters that follow the name of a computer file to show what it is. for example, the extension ‘.doc’ shows that a file is a written document..
(9) An extension lead.
(10) The position of a part of the body when it is stretched, or the process of stretching it.
(11) Part of a university or college that offers courses to people who are not full-time students.
(12) One of many telephone lines in a large building that all have different numbers, but that can be contacted through one central number.
Example: Put me through to extension 316, please.
(13) An additional period of time given to someone to finish a job, repay money that they owe etc.
Example: You can request an automatic four-month extension of the due date for paying your tax.
(14) When lenders agree to lend money for longer than was originally agreed.
Example: Lenders have given the retailer a five-year extension of a $87.4 million credit line.
(15) When a law, tax etc is changed to affect more things than before.
Example: An extension of the sales tax to various personal services and power utilities
(16) Another room or rooms that are added to a building.
Example: A 250-bedroom extension to the hotel will increase total capacity to 1,576 rooms.
(17) A set of three letters that follow the name of a computer file to show what it is. for example, the extension ‘.doc’ shows that a file is a written document.

(1) Large in size, amount, or degree.
Example: The house stands in extensive grounds. 
(2) Containing or dealing with a lot of information and details.
Example: Extensive research is being done into the connection between the disease and poor living conditions.

(1) Used to say how true something is or how great an effect or change is.
Example: We all to some extent remember the good times and forget the bad. 
(2) How large, important, or serious something is, especially something such as a problem or injury.
Example: Considering the extent of his injuries, hes lucky to be alive. 
(3) The length or size of something.
Example: They opened out the nets to their full extent .

(1) The outside of something, especially a building.
Example: The exterior of the factory 
(2) Behaviour that seems calm, unfriendly etc but which often hides a different feeling or attitude.
Example: Beneath that calm exterior, he has a fierce will to win. 
(3) On the outside of something.
Example: The exterior walls need a new coat of paint. 
(4) Exterior scenes in a film are filmed outdoors.
(5) Coming from or relating to facts, situations etc other than the one you are considering.
Example: Information that is exterior to the text itself

(1) Relating to the outside of something or of a person’s body.
Example: The external appearance of the building 
(2) Relating to your environment or situation, rather than to your own qualities, ideas etc.
Example: Low birth weight may be caused by external factors , such as smoking during pregnancy. 
(3) Coming from or happening outside a particular place or organization.
Example: Information from external sources 
(4) Relating to foreign countries.
Example: China will not tolerate any external interference in its affairs. 
(5) Coming from outside a particular school, university, or organization, and therefore independent.
(6) Coming from outside a company, organization, or country.
Example: The repayment of external debts

(1) An extinct type of animal or plant does not exist anymore.
Example: Dinosaurs have been extinct for millions of years. 
(2) If a type of person, custom, skill etc is extinct, it does not exist in society anymore.
(3) An extinct volcano does not erupt anymore.

(1) When a particular type of animal or plant stops existing.
Example: Species in danger of extinction 
(2) When a type of person, custom, skill etc stops existing.
Example: Their traditional way of life seems doomed to extinction.

(1) To make a fire or light stop burning or shining.
Example: Please extinguish all cigarettes. 
(2) To make an idea or feeling stop.
Example: All hope was almost extinguished. 
(3) To remove someone’s permission or right to do something.
Example: Any settlement extinguishes the plaintiffs title to that interest in the goods.
(4) To agree that a debt does not have to be paid.
Example: Death does not automatically extinguish debts on bank accounts.
(1) A fire extinguisher.

(1) To praise something very much.
Example: A speech extolling the merits of free enterprise

(1) More of something, in addition to the usual or standard amount or number.
Example: Could you get an extra loaf of bread? 
(2) If something is extra, it is not included in the price of something and you have to pay more for it.
Example: Dinner costs $15 but wine is extra.  15 
(3) In addition to the usual things or the usual amount.
Example: They need to offer something extra to attract customers. 
(4) Used to emphasize an adjective or adverb.
Example: Youre going to have to work extra hard to pass the exam. 
(5) An amount of something, especially money, in addition to the usual, basic, or necessary amount.
Example: I earn extra for working on sunday. 
(6) Something which is added to a basic product or service that improves it and often costs more.
Example: Tinted windows and a sunroof are optional extras (= something that you can choose to have or not ) . 
(7) An actor in a film who does not say anything but is part of a crowd.
Example: He started his acting career as an extra. 
(8) Outside or beyond.
Example: Extragalactic (= outside our galaxy ) 
(9) Very or more than normal.
Example: Extra-large 
(10) More than normal, or in addition to something else.
Example: We will be advertising for 200 extra staff.
(11) Something which is added on, especially charges on a bill.
Example: Cruise control is available as an optional extra .

(1) To remove an object from somewhere, especially with difficulty.
Example: Youll have to have that tooth extracted . 
(2) To carefully remove a substance from something which contains it, using a machine, chemical process etc.
Example: Oils are extracted from the plants. 
(3) To get something which you want from someone, such as information, money, help etc, especially when they do not want to give it to you.
Example: She had extracted a promise from him. 
(4) To take information or a short piece of writing from a book.
Example: We need to extract the relevant financial data. 
(5) To get an advantage or good thing from a situation.
Example: They aim to extract the maximum political benefit from the games. 
(6) A short piece of writing, music etc taken from a particular book, piece of music etc.
Example: Ive only seen short extracts from the film. 
(7) A substance obtained from something by using a special process.
Example: Add one teaspoon of vanilla extract. 
(8) To remove raw materials, such as gold or oil, from a place, for example the sea or the ground, so that they can be sold or used in an industrial or manufacturing process.
Example: The landowner has appealed for planning permission to extract the peat.
(9) To separate a substance or chemical from raw materials.
Example: The roots are crushed in the local sugar factory to extract the sugary juice.
(10) To get information or facts from a piece of writing or set of figures.
Example: The software extracts data directly from the accounting system.
(11) To get information or an agreement from someone, although it is difficult to do so.
Example: The full employment of the 1950s gave trade unions the power to extract better terms and conditions from employers.
(12) A small part of a piece of writing, music, or a film.
Example: An extract from a memorandum to a us delegate
(13) A substance or chemical which has been removed from raw materials.
Example: Vanilla extract
(1) Extracurricular activities are not part of the course that a student is doing at a school or college.

(1) Spending or costing a lot of money, especially more than is necessary or more than you can afford.

(1) Very great in degree.

Example: This kind of experiment seems cruel in the extreme.

(1) To a very great degree.
Example: Earthquakes are extremely difficult to predict.

(1) Someone who is active and confident, and who enjoys spending time with other people.

(1) Your ability to see.

(1) To make it easier for a process or activity to happen.

(1) An exact copy of a picture, piece of writing etc.

Example: The collection includes facsimiles of early english postage stamps.

(1) A piece of information that is known to be true.
Example: The book is full of facts about the world cup. 
(2) Used when talking about a situation and saying that it is true.
Example: Our decision to build the museum in hartlepool was influenced by the fact that there were no national museums in the north east. 
(3) Used when you are adding something, especially something surprising, to emphasize what you have just said.
Example: I know the mayor really well. in fact, i had dinner with her last week. 
(4) Used when you are telling someone what is actually true in a particular situation, especially when this may be difficult to accept, or different from what people believe.
Example: The fact of the matter is that hes just not up to the job. 
(5) Used to emphasize that what you are saying about a situation is true and people must realize this.
Example: The fact remains that the number of homeless people is rising daily. 
(6) Situations, events etc that really happened and have not been invented.
Example: Much of the novel is based on fact. 
(7) The basic details, numbers etc concerning a particular situation or subject.
Example: Here are a few facts and figures about the country. 
(8) Used to say that the things that have happened or the things someone has done show clearly that something is true.
(9) After something has happened or been done, especially after a mistake has been made.

(1) Based on facts or relating to facts.
Example: Try to keep your account of events as factual as possible.

(1) A department or group of related departments within a university.

(3) A natural ability, such as the ability to see, hear, or think clearly.
Example: The patients mental faculties 
(4) A particular skill that someone has.
Example: She had a great faculty for absorbing information.

(1) To gradually disappear.
Example: Hopes of a peace settlement are beginning to fade. 
(2) To lose colour and brightness, or to make something do this.
Example: The fading evening light 
(3) To become weaker physically, especially so that you become very ill or die.
(4) If a team fades, it stops playing as well as it did before.
(5) To seem unimportant.
Example: Our problems fade into insignificance when compared with those of the people here. 
(6) To appear slowly or become louder, or to make a picture or sound do this.
Example: Additional background sound is faded in at the beginning of the shot. 
(7) To disappear slowly or become quieter, or to make a picture or sound do this.
Example: He slid a control to fade out the music.

(1) A fair situation, system, way of treating people, or judgment seems reasonable, acceptable, and right.
Example: All we are asking for is a fair wage. 
(2) Treating everyone in a way that is right or equal.
Example: Why does eric get to go and i dont? its not fair ! 
(3) Quite a large size, number etc.
Example: Ive still got a fair amount of work left to do. 
(4) Someone who is fair, or who has fair hair or skin, has hair or skin that is very light in colour.
(5) A fair fight, game, or election is one that is played or done according to the rules.
(6) Neither particularly good nor particularly bad.
Example: Her written work is excellent but her practical work is only fair. 
(7) Weather that is fair is pleasant and not windy, rainy etc.
Example: It should be generally fair and warm for the next few days. 
(8) To have had more of something, especially something unpleasant, than seems reasonable.
Example: Poor old alan! hes had more than his fair share of bad luck recently. 
(9) To give someone the opportunity to do something, especially so that they can show that they are able to do it.
(10) To treat someone, or to be treated, in a way that gives everyone the same chances as everyone else.
Example: Women dont always get a fair shake in business. 
(11) Using any method to get what you want, including dishonest or illegal methods.
(12) Used to say that in some situations any method of getting what you want is acceptable.
(13) Pleasant and attractive.
Example: A fair maiden 
(14) Used to say that you agree with someone’s suggestion or that something seems reasonable.
Example: i think we should split the bill. fair enough.     
(15) Used when adding something after someone has been criticized, which helps to explain or excuse what they did.
Example: She should have phoned to tell us what her plans were although, to be fair, shes been very busy. 
(16) Used to tell someone not to be unreasonable or criticize someone too much.
Example: Now pat, be fair, the poor girls trying her hardest! 
(17) Used when you think it is fair that someone should do something, especially because of something that has happened earlier.
Example: Come on, fairs fair  i paid last time so its your turn.   
(18) Used to say that a remark or criticism seems reasonable.
(19) Used to say that an offer you are making to someone is the best and fairest offer they can possibly get.
Example: Ill give you 25 for it  you cant say fairer than that, can you?  25   
(20) Used humorously to admit that you should not be doing something that someone has caught you doing.
(21) If you do something with your own fair hands, you do it yourself without any help – used humorously.

(24) An event at which people or businesses show and sell their products.
Example: The frankfurt book fair 
(25) An event where people go to get information about different kinds of jobs.
(26) An outdoor event with games and things to eat and drink, usually organized to get money for a school, club etc.
(27) A market where animals and farm products are sold.
Example: A horse fair 
(28) To win a competition, sports match etc honestly and without cheating.
(29) To do something in a fair and honest way.
Example: In international trade, very few countries play fair. 
(30) A situation or arrangement which is fair is reasonable, honest, and acceptable.
Example: The committee takes seriously the need to be fair and just in everything it does.

Example: The frankfurt book fair

(1) More than a little, but much less than very.
Example: The house had a fairly large garden. 
(2) In a way that is fair, honest, and reasonable.
Example: I felt i hadnt been treated fairly. 
(3) Used to emphasize the degree, force etc of an action.
Example: He fairly raced past us on his bike.

(1) A strong feeling of trust or confidence in someone or something.
Example: I still have faith in him. 
(2) Belief and trust in god.
Example: Deep religious faith 
(3) To stop supporting or believing in a person, organization, or idea.
Example: How could he tell them the truth without breaking faith with the party? 
(4) To continue to support or believe in a person, organization, or idea.
(5) Honest and sincere intentions.
Example: He proposed a second meeting as a sign of his good faith. 
(6) Intentions that are not honest or sincere.
(7) Something you do that shows you trust someone completely.
Example: Allowing ken to be in charge of the project was a total act of faith. 
(8) Confidence that someone or something can be trusted or will work properly.
Example: We have faith in our staff.
(9) If you do something in good faith, you do not intend to deceive anyone and believe that what you are doing is honest.
Example: As a gesture of good faith, he deposited 1,000 with the business agents.
(10) If you do something in bad faith, you intend to deceive people.
Example: The jury found that all three accountants had acted in bad faith .

(1) A copy of a valuable object, painting etc that is intended to deceive people.
Example: The painting was judged a fake. 
(2) Someone who is not what they claim to be or does not have the skills they say they have.
Example: Her psychologist turned out to be a fake. 
(3) Made to look like a real material or object in order to deceive people.
Example: Fake fur 
(4) Not real and seeming to be something it is not, in order to deceive people.
Example: I gave a fake name. 
(5) To make something seem real in order to deceive people.
Example: She faked her fathers signature on the cheque. 
(6) To pretend to be ill, interested etc when you are not.
Example: I thought he was really hurt but he was faking it . 
(7) To pretend to move in one direction, but then move in another, especially when playing sport.
Example: He faked a pass. 
(8) To deceive someone by making them think you are planning to do something when you are really planning to do something else.
(9) Made to look like something valuable or genuine (=real) in order to deceive people.
Example: Fake rolex watches
(10) A copy of an original document, valuable object etc that is intended to deceive people into believing it is the real document, object etc.
Example: The signature on the contract proved to be a fake.
(11) To make an exact copy of something, or invent figures or results, in order to deceive people.
Example: She had faked her bosss signature on the cheque.

(1) Fallow land is dug or ploughed but is not used for growing crops.
Example: They let the land lie fallow for a year. 
(2) A time when nothing is done or achieved.
Example: The band went through a fallow period in the late 90s. 90

Example: Fallow land
(4) If land lies fallow, it is not being used to grow crops.
Example: The eu introduced incentives for farmers to let land lie fallow in order to reduce grain surpluses.
(5) A fallow period of time for a person or organization is one when they are not very active, productive, profitable etc.
Example: The pharmaceutical division emerged from a relatively fallow period, with increased profits this year.

(1) To like or want something, or want to do something.
Example: Fancy a quick drink, emma?

(1) Used to say who is intended to get or use something, or where something is intended to be used.

(2) To move somewhere with a lot of effort, especially because you are injured or tired.

(6) To force someone to go somewhere that they do not want to go, especially to prison.

Example: Campbell was hauled up in front of the magistrate. 
(8) A large amount of illegal or stolen goods.
Example: The gang escaped with a haul worth hundreds of pounds. 
(9) Something that takes a lot of time and effort.
Example: At last weve won our freedom but its been a long bitter haul . 
(10) Until something that will take a long time is done or achieved.
Example: Im in this for the long haul (= going to stay involved until the end ) .

Example: Over the long haul, these small increases add up. 
(12) The amount of fish caught when fishing with a net.
(13) If a train or truck hauls goods, it takes them from one place to another.
Example: The freight train hauled the load of 240 tons with ease.
(14) To officially make someone go to a senior manager, committee, or court to be judged on something they have done, especially something bad.
Example: Officials can be hauled before congressional committees and asked to justify their policies.
(15) To speak to someone angrily and severely because they have done something wrong.
Example: He might be hauled over the coals and forced to resign if his manager did not agree with his actions.
(16) The amount of fish caught in one net or in one period of time.
Example: Demand for fishing boats depends on estimated sizes of fish hauls.
(17) A large amount of stolen or illegal goods that has been found by the police or customs.
Example: A haul of stolen cars has been seized by police.
(18) Connected with long or short journeys by plane.
Example: Klm earns most of its revenue on long-haul flights .

(2) To stay nervously in the same place, especially because you are waiting for something or are not certain what to do.
Example: Her younger brother hovered in the background watching us. 
(3) If a level, price etc hovers around a certain amount, it stays close to that amount, only changing slightly up or down.
Example: The dollar has been hovering around the 110 yen level.  110 
(4) To put the cursor on something on a computer screen, using the mouse.
Example: When you hover the cursor over the image, the title of the image appears.

(1) Used when you are adding a fact or piece of information that seems surprising, or seems very different from what you have just said.
Example: This is a cheap and simple process. however, there are dangers. 
(2) Used to say that it does not matter how big, good, serious etc something is because it will not change a situation in any way.
Example: You should report any incident, however minor it is. 
(3) Used to show surprise when you ask how something happens or how someone does something.
Example: However did he get that job? 
(4) In whatever way.
Example: You can do it however you like.

(1) If a group of people huddle together, they stay very close to each other, especially because they are cold or frightened.
Example: We lay huddled together for warmth. 
(2) To lie or sit with your arms and legs close to your body because you are cold or frightened.
Example: She huddled under the blankets. 
(3) To sit or stand with a small group of people in order to discuss something privately.
Example: The executive board huddled to discuss the issue. 
(4) If american football players huddle, they gather around one player who tells them the plan for the next part of the game.
(5) A group of people or things that are close together, but not arranged in any particular order, pattern, or system.
Example: A huddle of straw huts 
(6) A group of players in american football who gather around one player who tells them the plan for the next part of the game.
(7) To form a small group away from other people in order to discuss something.

(1) To put your arms around someone and hold them tightly to show love or friendship.

(2) To put your arms around yourself.
Example: Sarah sat on the floor, hugging her knees. 
(3) To move along the side, edge, top etc of something, staying very close to it.

(4) If clothes hug your body, they fit closely.

(5) To hold something in your arms close to your chest.
Example: He was hugging a big pile of books. 
(6) To feel very pleased with yourself.
Example: Kate hugged herself with pleasure after receiving the award. 
(7) The action of putting your arms around someone and holding them tightly to show love or friendship.

(1) To sing a tune by making a continuous sound with your lips closed.

(2) To make a low continuous sound.

(1) Treating people or animals in a way that is not cruel and causes them as little suffering as possible.

(1) To carefully watch and check a situation in order to see how it changes over a period of time.

(1) If a company or government has a monopoly of a business or political activity, it has complete control of it so that other organizations cannot compete with it.

(4) A very popular type of board game that has been sold since the 1930s. players use toy money to buy streets and buildings on squares on the board, and then make other players pay rent if they move onto those squares. the squares on the board show the names of real streets in cities in the us (=in an american monopoly set), london (=in a british monopoly set), or other big cities around the world. people sometimes use the expression monopoly money to mean a very large amount of money.
Example: You know how much it costs to buy an apartment in tokyo? it's monopoly money!

(1) Relating to the principles of what is right and wrong behaviour, and with the difference between good and evil.

(1) Beliefs or ideas about what is right and wrong and about how people should behave.

(1) If you have a preference for something, you like it more than another thing and will choose it if you can.
Example: Do you have a colour preference ? 
(2) When someone is treated more favourably than other people, often when he or she has been treated unfairly in the past.
Example: Racial preferences are a way to make up for years of discrimination against minorities. 
(3) Someone’s sexual preference is whether they want to have sex with men or women.
(4) The state of liking something more than something else, or something you like more than another thing.
Example: People were twice as likely to change their brand preference if they liked an advertisement.
(5) When a country treats some countries more favourably than others in international trade, for example through lower import taxes.
Example: Britain must take a strong line with its trading partners, but without damaging community preference (= treating goods from the european union more favourably than others. )

(1) When a woman is pregnant (=has a baby growing inside her body).
Example: This drug should not be taken during pregnancy.

(1) If a woman or female animal is pregnant, she has an unborn baby growing inside her body.
Example: Medical care for pregnant women 
(2) A pause or silence which is full of meaning or emotion.
Example: He stopped, and there was a pregnant pause. 
(3) Containing a lot of a quality.
Example: Every phrase in this poem is pregnant with meaning.

(1) Happening before something that is more important, often in order to prepare for it.
Example: The preliminary stages of the competition 
(2) Something that is said or done first, to introduce or prepare for something else.
Example: Pilot studies are a useful preliminary to large research projects. 
(3) One of the games in the first part of a competition, when it is decided who will go on to the main competition.
Example: Four teams will be eliminated in the preliminaries. 
(4) Coming before something more official, more important etc.
Example: Preliminary estimates indicate that earnings will decline substantially from a year ago.

(1) Best or most important.
Example: One of dublins premier hotels 
(2) A prime minister – used in news reports.
Example: The irish premier 
(3) Most successful or important.
Example: The premier bond-trading firm on wall street

(1) The buildings and land that a shop, restaurant, company etc uses.
Example: Schools may earn extra money by renting out their premises. 
(2) A statement or idea that you accept as true and use as a base for developing other ideas.
Example: The idea that there is life on other planets is the central premise of the novel.

(1) The cost of insurance, especially the amount that you pay each year.
Example: Insurance premiums 
(2) An additional amount of money, above a standard rate or amount.
Example: Consumers are prepared to pay a premium for organically grown vegetables. 
(3) If something is at a premium, people need it or want it, but there is little of it available or it is difficult to get.
Example: During the olympic games, accommodation will be at a premium. 
(4) To consider one quality or type of thing as being much more important than others.
Example: Modern economies place a premium on educated workers. 
(5) Good quality petrol.
(6) Of very high quality.
Example: Premium ice cream 
(7) Premium prices and rates are higher than usual ones.
Example: People are prepared to pay premium prices for quality products. 
(8) A payment that you make for insurance.
Example: Some insurance companies offer small sum policies, with monthly or annual premiums .
(9) An additional amount of money, above a standard amount or rate.
Example: The companys earnings will grow by about 25% a year and investors will be willing to pay a premium (= pay more than usual ) for that growth.
(10) If something is at a premium, there is little of it available or it is difficult to obtain.
Example: With parking space at a premium in japanese cities, the microcar is a popular form of transport.
(11) If one thing is sold at a premium to another, it costs more.
Example: Platinum usually trades at a premium to gold.
(12) If you put a premium on something, you consider it to be especially valuable.
Example: Employers today put a premium on reasoning skills and willingness to learn.
(13) Premium products, goods etc are of higher quality than usual.
Example: Premium brands of beer will grow faster, in line with the trend toward people demanding better quality.

(1) The process of preparing something or preparing for something.
Example: This dish is good for dinner parties because much of the preparation can be done ahead of time. 
(2) Arrangements for something that is going to happen.
Example: Preparations for the upcoming olympic games are nearing completion. 
(3) A mixture that has been prepared and that is used for a particular purpose, especially as a medicine or to make your skin more attractive.
Example: A new preparation for cleansing the skin

(1) To make a meal or a substance.
Example: Prepare the sauce while the pasta is cooking. 
(2) To make plans or arrangements for something that will happen in the future.
Example: The 45-year-old explorer has been preparing for his latest expedition to the arctic.  45 
(3) To make something ready to be used.
Example: Prepare the soil, then plant the seedlings eight inches apart. 
(4) To make yourself mentally or physically ready for something that you expect to happen soon.
Example: The letter arrived, and we prepared ourselves for bad news. 
(5) To provide someone with the training, skills, experience etc that they will need to do a job or to deal with a situation.
Example: A course that prepares students for english examinations 
(6) To make it possible for something to be achieved, or for someone to succeed in doing something.
Example: Curies research prepared the way for the work of modern nuclear scientists.

(1) Something that is necessary before something else can happen or be done.
Example: A reasonable proficiency in english is a prerequisite for the course.

(1) To say what medicine or treatment a sick person should have.
Example: If these dont work i may have to prescribe you something stronger. 
(2) To state officially what should be done in a particular situation.
Example: What punishment does the law prescribe for this crime?

(1) A piece of paper on which a doctor writes what medicine a sick person should have, so that they can get it from a pharmacist.
Example: A prescription for sleeping pills 
(2) A particular medicine or treatment ordered by a doctor for a sick person.
Example: If youre pregnant, you can get free prescriptions. 
(3) A drug that you get on prescription can only be obtained with a written order from the doctor.
(4) An idea or suggestion about how you should behave, or how to make a situation, activity etc successful.
Example: The partys main prescription for educational problems was to give schools more money.

(1) When someone or something is present in a particular place.
Example: Your presence is requested at the club meeting on friday. 
(2) With someone or in the same place as them.
Example: He was determined not to complain in the presence of the nurse. 
(3) The ability to appear impressive to people because of your appearance or the way you behave.
Example: A man of great presence 
(4) A group of people, especially soldiers, who are in a place to control what is happening.
Example: We will increase police presence in local communities. 
(5) The ability to gain sales because your business is strong or noticeable.
Example: A company with a strong presence in all major world markets 
(6) A spirit or influence that cannot be seen but is felt to be near.
Example: They felt a strange presence in the deserted house. 
(7) To have a strong and noticeable effect on the people around you or the situation you are in.
Example: She was a very pretty girl and made her presence felt almost at once.

(1) The act of giving someone a prize or present at a formal ceremony.
Example: The presentation ceremony 
(2) An event at which you describe or explain a new product or idea.
Example: We will begin a series of presentations to help the public fully understand our system. 
(3) The way in which something is said, offered, shown, or explained to others.
Example: Desktop devices for the presentation of information 
(4) When you show something to someone so that it can be checked or considered.
Example: The presentation of the identity documents 
(5) The act of performing a play.
Example: I went to see the national theatres presentation of arthur millers the last yankee.   
(6) The position in which a baby is lying in its mother’s body just before it is born.
Example: A breech presentation 
(7) A book that is given to someone, especially by the writer or publisher.
(8) An event at which a new product, idea, plan etc is described and explained.
Example: A slick multimedia presentation
(9) The way in which something is said, shown, or explained to others.
Example: The group has taken the opportunity to overhaul the presentation of its annual report.

(1) To save something or someone from being harmed or destroyed.
Example: We must encourage the planting of new trees and preserve our existing woodlands. 
(2) To make something continue without changing.
Example: The responsibility of the police to preserve the peace 
(3) To store food for a long time after treating it so that it will not decay.
Example: Black olives preserved in brine 
(4) A substance made from boiling fruit or vegetables with sugar, salt, or vinegar.
Example: Homemade fruit preserves 
(5) An activity that is only suitable or allowed for a particular group of people.
Example: Banking used to be a male preserve . 
(6) An area of land or water that is kept for private hunting or fishing.

(1) An attempt to persuade someone by using influence, arguments, or threats.
Example: They are putting pressure on people to vote yes. 
(2) A way of working or living that causes you a lot of anxiety, especially because you feel you have too many things to do.
Example: I feel im not able to cope well with the pressures of life. 
(3) Events or conditions that cause changes and affect the way a situation develops, especially in economics or politics.
Example: Inflationary pressures 
(4) The force or weight that is being put on to something.
Example: The pressure of the water turns the wheel. 
(5) The force produced by the quantity of gas or liquid in a place or container.
Example: The gas containers burst at high pressure . 
(6) A condition of the air in the earth’s atmosphere, which affects the weather.
Example: A ridge of high pressure is building up strongly over the atlantic. 
(7) To try to make someone do something by making them feel it is their duty to do it.
Example: You want to enjoy food, not to be pressured into eating the right things.

(1) Used to say that you think something is probably true.
Example: Its raining, which presumably means that your football match will be cancelled.

(1) To depend on something that is believed to exist or to be true.
Example: The idea of heaven presupposes the existence of god. 
(2) To have to happen if something is true.
Example: Without struggle there can be no progress, and struggle presupposes winners and losers.

(1) To behave as if something is true when in fact you know it is not, in order to deceive people or for fun.
Example: We cant go on pretending that everything is ok. 
(2) To claim that something is true, when it is not.
Example: I cant pretend i understand these technical terms (= i admit i do not understand them ) . 
(3) Imaginary or not real – used especially by children.
Example: We sang songs around a pretend campfire.

(1) An attempt to seem more important, more intelligent, or of a higher class than you really are.
Example: Lilith resented adams pretensions to superiority. 
(2) A claim to be or do something.
Example: The group dont have any pretensions to be pop stars.

(1) If someone or something is pretentious, they try to seem more important, intelligent, or high class than they really are in order to be impressive.
Example: A pretentious film

(1) If a belief, custom, situation etc prevails, it exists among a group of people at a certain time.
Example: The economic conditions which prevail in england and wales 
(2) If a person, idea, or principle prevails in a fight, argument etc, they are successful in the end.
Example: Justice will prevail. 
(3) To persuade someone.
Example: She prevailed upon her father to say nothing. 
(4) If someone or their arguments, views etc prevail, they finally win an argument after a long period of time.
Example: The company is hoping to prevail in a court challenge to the water board ruling.
(5) If an attitude or belief prevails, it continues to exist in a particular situation.
Example: Pessimism and gloom have continued to prevail about britains economic expectations.

(1) Common at a particular time, in a particular place, or among a particular group of people.
Example: Solvent abuse is especially prevalent among younger teenagers. 
(2) Frequent or common at a particular time or in a particular situation.
Example: Sexual harassment is prevalent in the workplace.

(1) Preventive.
Example: Preventative measures

(1) Having happened or existed before the event, time, or thing that you are talking about now.
Example: Ive met him before on two previous occasions. 
(2) The one that came immediately before the one you are talking about now.
Example: I had met them the previous day. 
(3) Before a particular time or event.
Example: There were almost no women mps previous to 1945. 1945

(1) An animal, bird etc that is hunted and eaten by another animal.
Example: A tiger stalking its prey 
(2) A bird or animal which lives by killing and eating other animals.
(3) If someone falls prey to someone or something bad, they are harmed or affected by them.
Example: Street children in this part of the world often fall prey to drug dealers. 
(4) Someone who can easily be deceived or harmed.
Example: He was easy prey for the two conmen who called at his house. 
(5) If an animal or bird preys on another animal or bird, it hunts and eats it.
Example: Cats prey on birds and mice. 
(6) If an animal or bird preys on another animal or bird, it hunts and eats it.
Example: Cats prey on birds and mice. 
(7) To try to deceive or harm weaker people.
Example: Religious cults that specialize in preying on young people 
(8) To make someone worry continuously.
Example: The accident has been preying on my mind all week. 
(9) The target company (=the company that another company wants to buy) in a takeover.
Example: Min would prefer to be predator (= a company that buys another company ) rather than prey, but it was outbid in its last attempt to buy a regional newspaper.
(10) To be unable to avoid a harmful or difficult situation.
Example: After opening higher, the otc market fell prey to profit-taking.

(1) Mainly.
Example: The advertisement is aimed primarily at children.

(1) Most important.
Example: Our primary concern is to provide the refugees with food and health care. 
(2) Relating to the education of children between 5 and 11 years old.
Example: A primary teacher 
(3) Happening or developing before other things.
Example: A primary tumour 
(4) A primary election.
(5) A primary school.
(6) Main or most important.
Example: Its primary business is developing and marketing new software.
(7) Relating to shares, bonds etc when they are issued (=sold for the first time), and the markets where they are sold, rather than shares etc that are traded later.
Example: The primary bond market

(1) Most important.
Example: Smoking is the prime cause of lung disease. 
(2) Of the very best quality or kind.
Example: Prime rib of beef 
(3) To be the person or thing that is most suitable or most likely to be chosen for a particular purpose.
Example: The school is a prime candidate for closure. 
(4) A very typical example of something.
Example: Blakey hall is a prime example of a 19th-century building.  19 
(5) The time in your life when you are strongest and most active.
Example: Shes now 40 and still in her prime. 
(6) To prepare someone for a situation so that they know what to do.
Example: Did you prime her with what to say? 
(7) To prepare a gun or bomb so that it can fire or explode.
(8) To put a special layer of paint on a surface, in order to prepare it for the next layer.
Example: All metal surfaces will have to be primed. 
(9) To encourage a business, industry, or activity to develop by putting money or effort into it.
(10) To pour water into a water pump in order to make it ready to work.
(11) Of the best quality.
Example: Acres of prime real estate right by an international airport
(12) Main or most important.
Example: The developers prime objective is to build houses at maximum profit, with minimum care for the environment.
(13) To make the economy grow faster by increasing government spending, hoping that this will encourage business to invest more.
Example: Direct investments in job creation are essential to prime the pump and get the economy up and running again.
(14) Used to talk about how much higher an interest rate is than the prime rate (=the interest rate charged by banks to their best borrowers).
Example: The working-capital loan carried an interest rate of 3 points above prime.

(1) Belonging to a simple way of life that existed in the past and does not have modern industries and machines.
Example: A primitive society 
(2) Something that is primitive is very simple and does not have the extra modern parts that would make it faster, better, more comfortable etc.
Example: The first station buildings were quite primitive. 
(3) A primitive animal or plant has a simple structure or body.
Example: Primitive life-forms that live deep in the ocean 
(4) Primitive feelings are not based on reason, and seem to come from a part of people’s character that is ancient and animal-like.
Example: The primitive instinct of survival 
(5) An artist who paints simple pictures like those of a child.

(1) Most important.
Example: His principal reason for making the journey was to visit his family. 
(2) Someone who is in charge of a school.
Example: A small school with just three teachers and the principal 
(3) Someone who is in charge of a university or college.
(4) The main person in a business or organization, who can make important business decisions and is legally responsible for them.
Example: The principal of the business has an office in new york. 
(5) The main performer in a play or in a group of musicians, dancers etc.
Example: She later became a principal with the royal ballet. 
(6) The original amount of money that is lent to someone, not including any of the interest.
(7) The original amount of a loan, not including any of the interest that is paid.
Example: The loan amounts outstanding totaled about $32.2 million in principal and $2.2 million in interest.
(8) An important person, manager etc in some types of organization, who may be legally responsible for its actions.
Example: Mr o'brien is a principal of the law and economics consulting group.
(9) The actual buyer and the seller in a business deal, rather than the people who represent them, or brokers who buy and sell for them.
Example: None of the principals would comment on the purchase price.
(10) Most important.
Example: Portland is one of the principal unloading points for japanese automobiles.
(11) Relating to the original amount of a loan, rather than any interest.
Example: The total principal amount of debentures being sold was increased to $75 million.

(1) A moral rule or belief about what is right and wrong, that influences how you behave.
Example: Schools try to teach children a set of principles. 
(2) The basic idea that a plan or system is based on.
Example: The general principle is that education should be available to all children up to the age of 16.  16 
(3) If something is possible in principle, there is no good reason why it should not happen, but it has not actually happened yet.
Example: In principle, the new software should make the accounting system a lot simpler. 
(4) A rule which explains the way something such as a machine works, or which explains a natural force in the universe.
Example: Archimedes principle 
(5) A moral rule or set of ideas that makes you behave in a particular way.
Example: The single european market works on market principles.
(6) A rule that explains how something works, or an idea that something is based on.
Example: The basic principle is that all information collected for one purpose is confidential.
(7) If something is possible in principle, there is no reason why it should not happen, but it has not actually happened yet.
Example: In principle, we pay all our freelance staff within one month.
(8) If something happens in principle, decisions, rules etc say that it should happen, even if in practice it does not always happen.
Example: In principle, a hostile takeover is possible, but we want to discourage it.
(9) If you agree to do something in principle, you agree in a general way to the idea or plan, without agreeing to any details.
Example: North and south korea agreed in principle to link their separate air-traffic control systems.

(1) Existing or arranged before something else or before the present situation.
Example: You do not need any prior knowledge of the subject. 
(2) A warning or announcement made before something happens.
Example: The society must give customers prior notice before changing the cost. 
(3) Before.
Example: All the arrangements should be completed prior to your departure. 
(4) A person’s right to something which is considered more important than another person’s right to the same thing.
Example: His own children have a prior claim to the business. 
(5) The man in charge of a priory.
(6) The priest next in rank to the person in charge of an abbey.
(7) A previous occasion when someone was found guilty of a crime.
Example: Two priors for homicide 
(8) Coming before something is finally decided, agreed etc.
Example: Most firms require prior approval of analysts personal trades before selling stock to them.

(1) The thing that you think is most important and that needs attention before anything else.
Example: The clubs priority is to win the league. 
(2) The right to be given attention first and before other people or things.
Example: Buses should have priority over other road users. 
(3) To know what is most important and needs attention first.
Example: We need to get our priorities right. 
(4) Before other people or things.
Example: Members receive priority bookings and reduced ticket prices to all concerts. 
(5) The thing that is more important than anything else, and that needs attention first.
Example: Cost-cutting measures continue to be the first priority at the company.
(6) To be considered more important or needing more attention than anything else and therefore dealt with first.
Example: Workers accepting redundancy will have priority for jobs elsewhere at g.m.

(1) The state of being able to be alone, and not seen or heard by other people.
Example: With seven people squashed in one house, you dont get much privacy. 
(2) The state of being free from public attention.
Example: Each individuals right to privacy

(1) For use by one person or group, not for everyone.
Example: Morris has a private jet. 
(2) Not related to, owned by, or paid for by the government.
Example: A private hospital 
(3) A private meeting, conversation etc involves only two people or a small number of people, and is not for other people to know about.
Example: I need to have a private discussion with you. 
(4) Private feelings, information, or opinions are personal or secret and not for other people to know about.
Example: Jacks private opinion was that she was selfish. 
(5) Used about someone who is not known to the public or not working for the government or another organization.
Example: A private citizen 
(6) Separate from and not related to your work or your official position.
Example: The president is paying a private visit to europe. 
(7) Quiet and without a lot of people.
Example: Why dont we go upstairs where its more private? 
(8) A private person is one who likes being alone, and does not talk much about their thoughts or feelings.
Example: Hes a very private man. 
(9) A joke made between friends, family members etc that other people do not understand.
(10) Without other people being present.
Example: I need to speak to you in private. 
(11) A soldier of the lowest rank.
(12) Private parts.
(13) Private property, businesses, activities etc are owned or paid for by people and companies, rather than the government.
Example: They transferred ownership of thousands of companies from the state to the private sector (= the part of the economy not owned by the government ) .
(14) Involving something that is sold directly to people or organizations, without being offered openly for anyone to buy.
Example: The company has raised $50 million in a private placement arranged by kemper financial services.
(15) Not belonging to the government.
Example: Slovak officials approved proposals to put 200 companies in private hands.
(16) Belonging to a member of the public rather than to an organization.
Example: There are more than 100 million handguns in private hands in the us.
(17) If a government-owned organization goes or turns private, it is sold to investors.
Example: Iberia airlines will be ready to go private next year.
(18) To pay for medical treatment instead of getting it free at a public hospital.
(19) A private company does not make its shares available for anyone to buy on a stockmarket.
Example: Cargill, the largest private company in the us, wants to stay that way. says mr west, a vice president: well go public (= sell shares on the stockmarket ) the week after snowballs form in hell.
(20) If a company with shares on the stockmarket goes private, its owners buy back those shares from existing shareholders so that it becomes privately owned.
Example: The majority of companies that went private in the last few years will become public again by reselling stock.
(21) If a company’s owners take it private, they buy back all shares from existing shareholders.
Example: The companys chairman plans to take the company private through a buy-out of the 74% of shares he doesnt already own.
(22) Only for use by one particular person or group, not for everyone.
Example: A private road
(23) A private meeting, agreement, conversation etc involves only a small number of people and is kept secret.
Example: Mr. miscio rose to protest, saying this is a private meeting.

(1) A special advantage that is given only to one person or group of people.
Example: He had no special privileges and was treated just like every other prisoner. 
(2) Something that you are lucky to have the chance to do, and that you enjoy very much.
Example: Today, we have the privilege of listening to two very unusual men. 
(3) A situation in which people who are rich or of a high social class have many more advantages than other people.
Example: Wealth and privilege 
(4) A situation in which doctors, lawyers etc are allowed to keep information about their discussions with their patients or clients secret from other people.
(5) The right to do or say something unacceptable without being punished, especially in parliament.
(6) To treat some people or things better than others.
(7) A special advantage given to a small group of people, organizations, countries etc.
Example: The new trade privileges will enhance viennas effort to attract us companies.
(8) A right in law that protects a person, for example by not forcing them to discuss something, or allowing them freedom to say things that would not normally be acceptable.
Example: Ms. backiel asserted the attorney-client privilege and refused to discuss the case.

(1) How likely something is, sometimes calculated in a mathematical way.
Example: The probability of winning the lottery is really very low. 
(2) What is likely or something that is likely.
Example: The probability is that smaller businesses will not have to pay the tax. 
(3) Very probably.
Example: Mistakes could and, in all probability, would occur. 
(4) The chance that something will happen, calculated mathematically.
Example: Companies may collaborate (= work together ) in working out loss probabilities.

(1) Likely to exist, happen, or be true.
Example: The probable cause of the fire was faulty wiring. 
(2) Someone who is likely to be chosen for a team, to win a race etc.

(1) A system that allows some criminals not to go to prison or to leave prison, if they behave well and see a probation officer regularly, for a particular period of time.
Example: The judge sentenced jennings to three years probation. 
(2) A period of time, during which an employer can see if a new worker is suitable.
Example: A three-month probation period 
(3) A period of time in which you must improve your work or behave well so that you will not have to leave your job.
Example: Im afraid i have no choice but to put you on probation . 
(4) A period of time during which a new employee is tested to make sure they are suitable for a job.
Example: At the end of the year i can pass or fail or have my probation extended.
(5) A fixed period of time during which a person or company must improve their performance if they are to continue working, trading etc.
Example: Calpers said it was placing salomon on probation, meaning it could sever all its business ties with the firm.
(6) A system of dealing with criminals which allows them not to go to prison, if they behave well and see an official adviser regularly, for a fixed period of time.
Example: Two of the accused were sentenced to prison terms, and the third received 10 months probation.

(1) To ask questions in order to find things out, especially things that other people do not want you to know.
Example: I dont want to probe too deeply into your personal affairs. 
(2) To look for something or examine something, using a long thin object.
Example: Jules probed the mud gingerly with a stick. 
(3) A long thin metal instrument that doctors and scientists use to examine parts of the body.
(4) A space probe.
(5) An investigation in which many questions are asked to discover the truth about something.
Example: A police corruption probe 
(6) A very thorough examination of something that has happened.
Example: The probe focuses on an unauthorized bid placed by the company two months ago.
(7) To ask very detailed questions to find something out, especially things people do not want you to know.
Example: To probe further, i called economist john mueller.

(1) A way of doing something, especially the correct or usual way.
Example: Whats the procedure for applying for a visa? 
(2) A medical treatment or operation.
Example: Liposuction is a minor surgical procedure . 
(3) The official or accepted way of doing something, especially something that is done often.
Example: We have hired an accounting firm to evaluate our audit procedures.

(1) To continue to do something that has already been planned or started.
Example: The government was determined to proceed with the election. 
(2) To continue.
Example: Work is proceeding according to plan . 
(3) To do something after doing something else first – used sometimes to express surprise or annoyance.
Example: Sammy took off his coat and proceeded to undo his boots. 
(4) To move in a particular direction.
Example: Passengers for miami should proceed to gate 25.  25 
(5) To begin a legal case against someone.
(6) To happen or exist as a result of something.
Example: Ideas that proceed from a disturbed state of mind 
(7) If you proceed to the next part of an activity, job etc, you do or take part in the next part of it.
Example: Players who proceed to the finals of the competition 
(8) To continue to do something that has been started.
Example: The discussions between the two firms are proceeding slowly but satisfactorily.

(1) A series of actions that are done in order to achieve a particular result.
Example: The israeliegyptian peace process 
(2) A series of things that happen naturally and result in gradual change.
Example: The natural process of evolution 
(3) To have started doing something and not yet be finished.
Example: The company is in the process of moving to new offices. 
(4) If something is in process, it is happening now.
Example: There was an armed revolt in process. 
(5) While you are doing something or something is happening.
Example: I spilt the coffee, burning myself in the process. 
(6) A way of finding the right answer, the truth etc by gradually deciding that none of the other answers etc are possible.
Example: I solved the problem by a process of elimination. 
(7) A method of making or producing goods.
Example: The car production process 
(8) To make food, materials, or goods ready to be used or sold, for example by preserving or improving them in some way.
Example: Goats cheese may be processed in many ways. 
(9) To deal with an official document, request etc in the usual way.
Example: All university applications are processed through this system. 
(10) To deal with information using a computer.
Example: The new network will enable data to be processed more speedily.
