(5) To be a sign or mark that means something.
Example: Brown areas represent deserts on the map. 
(6) To be a symbol of something.
Example: He hated the school and everything it represented. 
(7) If you represent your country, school, town etc in a sport, you take part in a sports event for that country etc.
Example: Her greatest ambition was to represent her country at the olympics. 
(8) If a group, organization, area etc is represented at an event, people from it are at the event.
Example: All the local clubs were represented in the parade. 
(9) To describe someone or something in a particular way, especially in a way that is not true.
Example: The article represents the millionaire as a simple family man. 
(10) If a painting, statue, piece of music etc represents something or someone, it shows them.
Example: Paintings representing religious themes were common in medieval times. 
(11) To speak or go somewhere officially in order to state the views, opinions etc of another person or group of people.
Example: Workers hired during the strike are opposed to being represented by the union.
(12) If something represents a proportion of something else, it is equal to it.
Example: The sale represents only 1.6% of the companys average daily production.
(13) If part of a graph, chart etc represents something, it shows that information.
Example: The blue line represents the target income for the planning period.

(1) Someone who has been chosen to speak, vote, or make decisions for someone else.
Example: A union representative 
(3) A member of the house of representatives, the lower house of congress in the united states.
(4) Typical of a particular group or thing.
Example: The latest incident is representative of a wider trend. 
(5) Including examples of all the different types of something in a group.
Example: The pollsters asked a representative sample of new york residents for their opinions. 
(6) A representative system of government allows people to vote for other people to represent them in the government.
Example: A representative democracy 
(7) A person who sells a company’s products or services by speaking to customers on the phone or travelling to meet them.
Example: The work of a sales representative includes after-sales service.
(8) Someone chosen to speak or make decisions for another person or group of people.
Example: Make sure your employees representatives are involved.
(9) Like other members of the same group, and therefore showing what they are all like.
Example: Unfortunately, your sample is not statistically representative of the population.

(1) If an animal or plant reproduces, or reproduces itself, it produces young plants or animals.
Example: The turtles return to the coast to reproduce. 
(2) To make a photograph or printed copy of something.
Example: Klimts artwork is reproduced in this exquisite book. 
(3) To make something happen in the same way as it happened before.
Example: British scientists have so far been unable to reproduce these results. 
(4) To make something that is just like something else.
Example: With a good set of speakers, you can reproduce the orchestras sound in your own home.

(1) A type of animal, such as a snake or lizard, whose body temperature changes according to the temperature around it, and that usually lays eggs to have babies.
(2) Someone who is unpleasant or cannot be trusted.

(1) Respected for being honest or for doing good work.
Example: If you have a burglar alarm fitted, make sure it is done by a reputable company. 
(2) Respected for honesty and good work.
Example: Consumers should buy only from reputable dealers offering unconditional guarantees.

(1) The opinion that people have about someone or something because of what has happened in the past.
Example: Judge kelso has a reputation for being strict but fair. 
(2) The opinion people have of something or someone, based on what has happened in the past.
Example: The firm has a very good reputation .

(1) A polite or formal demand for something.
Example: They have made an urgent request for international aid. 
(2) A piece of music that is played on the radio because someone has asked for it.
(3) To ask for something in a polite or formal way.
Example: To request more information, please call our toll-free number. 
(4) To officially or formally ask for something.
Example: Enclosed, please find the information you requested.
(5) An official or formal demand for something.
Example: The fund group received 150,000 requests for its prospectus.

(1) To need something.
Example: Campbells broken leg will probably require surgery. 
(2) If you are required to do or have something, a law or rule says you must do it or have it.
Example: You are required by law to wear a seat belt. 
(3) To officially demand that people do something, because of a law or rule.
Example: The ruling requiring companies to disclose the value of stock
(4) To need something.
Example: At first, cd-roms required a special disk drive that cost around $700.

(1) Something that someone needs or asks for.
Example: The refugees main requirements are food and shelter. 
(2) Something that must be done because of a law or rule.
Example: If you are installing a new bathroom, it has to meet the requirements of the building regulations. 
(3) Something, especially good examination results, that a college, employer etc says you must have in order to do something.
Example: English 4 is a requirement for english majors. 
(4) Something that an official organization says a company or person must have or do.
Example: There are deed restrictions, including a requirement that the buyer live in the property.
(5) Something that someone needs or wants.
Example: A product that meets customer requirements

(1) Needed for a particular purpose.
Example: He lacks the requisite qualifications. 
(2) Something that is needed for a particular purpose.
Example: He lacked the moral requisites for marriage. 
(3) Needed for a particular purpose.
Example: The financiers may be willing to step in and provide the requisite guarantees.

(1) If someone in authority, especially the army, requisitions a building, vehicle, or food, they officially demand to have it during an emergency such as a war.
Example: The building was requisitioned as a military hospital for the duration of the war. 
(2) An official written order for something.
Example: Government aircraft requisitions
(3) To officially ask for something in writing.
Example: One of its stakeholders has requisitioned an extraordinary general meeting.

(1) To save someone or something from a situation of danger or harm.
Example: Survivors of the crash were rescued by helicopter. 
(2) When someone or something is rescued from danger.
Example: A daring rescue at sea 
(3) To save someone who is in a dangerous situation.
Example: A lifeboat came to the yachtsmans rescue. 
(4) To save a company, country, or economic system that is in danger of failing, for example because of financial problems.
Example: The fund is aimed at rescuing financially troubled companies.
(5) An occasion when a company, country, or economic system is saved from failing.
Example: The company faces bankruptcy unless a rescue can be negotiated.
(6) An attempt, effort etc to save a company, country, or economic system from failing.
Example: Its an ambitious rescue effort, and some marketing experts question whether the strategy will be effective.

(1) To look like or be similar to someone or something.
Example: Its amazing how closely brian and steve resemble each other.

(1) To feel angry or upset about a situation or about something that someone has done, especially because you think that it is not fair.
Example: I resented having to work such long hours.

(1) An arrangement which you make so that a place in a hotel, restaurant, plane etc is kept for you at a particular time in the future.
Example: A dinner reservation 
(2) A feeling of doubt because you do not agree completely with a plan, idea, or suggestion.
Example: I had serious reservations about his appointment as captain. 
(3) An area of land in the us kept separate for native americans to live on.
Example: A navajo reservation 
(4) An area of land where wild animals can live without being hunted.
Example: A wildlife reservation 
(5) An arrangement in which a place on a plane, in a hotel, in a restaurant etc is kept for a customer who will arrive later.
Example: Every passenger is guaranteed a seat without a reservation.

(1) To arrange for a place in a hotel, restaurant, plane etc to be kept for you to use at a particular time in the future.
Example: Id like to reserve a table for two. 
(2) To keep something so that it can be used by a particular person or for a particular purpose.
Example: A separate room is reserved for smokers. 
(3) To keep part of something for use at a later time during a process – used especially when describing how to cook something.
Example: Reserve a little of the mixture to sprinkle over the top of the pie. 
(4) To use or show something only in one particular situation.
Example: She spoke in a tone of voice she usually reserved for dealing with officials. 
(5) If you reserve the right to do something, you will do it if you think it is necessary – used especially in notices or official documents.
Example: The management reserves the right to refuse admission. 
(6) To not give your opinion about something until a later time when you have more information.
(7) A supply of something kept to be used if it is needed.
Example: $10 million in cash reserves 1,000 
(8) Ready to be used if needed.
Example: We always keep some money in reserve , just in case. 
(9) A quality in someone’s character that makes them not like expressing their emotions or talking about their problems.
Example: She overcame her own natural reserve . 
(10) An extra player who plays in a team if one of the other players is injured or ill.
(11) A team that plays when the usual team cannot do so.
(12) An extra military force that a country has in addition to its usual army, navy etc which can be used if needed.
(13) An area of land where wild animals and plants are protected.
Example: A wildlife reserve 
(14) A reservation.
(15) A price below which something will not be sold, especially in an auction.
(16) To arrange for a place on a plane, in a hotel, in a restaurant etc to be kept for a customer who will arrive later.
Example: He reserved two rooms at the hotel.
(17) To keep or restrict something so that it can be used only by a particular person or for a particular purpose.
Example: Of the total capital, 19% is expected to be reserved for strategic investors.
(18) To state in an agreement, contract etc that you want the opportunity to do something or change something.
Example: The company reserved the right to invest directly in some of the movies.
(19) A statement put onto printed, recorded, or electronic material to show it is illegal to copy it without special permission.
(20) To delay a decision or opinion about something until a later date.
Example: The five-judge panel will reserve judgement until they see further evidence.
(21) A minimum price that a seller will accept, usually in an auction.
Example: The painting failed to reach its reserve (= was not sold because the minimum price was not offered ) .

(1) Unwilling to express your emotions or talk about your problems.
Example: Ellen was a shy, reserved girl.

(1) A house, especially a large or official one.
Example: The ambassadors official residence 
(2) Legal permission to live in a country for a certain period of time.
Example: A residence permit 
(3) The state of living in a place.
Example: Rome was his main place of residence . 
(4) An artist etc who has been officially chosen by a college or other institution to work there.
(5) To start living in a place.
Example: He took up residence in chicago. 
(6) Living in a place at a particular time.
Example: The emperor was in residence at his summer palace. 
(7) The fact of living in a particular place.
Example: Insurance companies use place of residence to calculate automobile insurance rates.
(8) Permission to live in a particular country permanently.
Example: An application for permanent residence
(9) A house where people live.
Example: Florida law protects personal residences against seizure in bankruptcy law.

(1) Someone who lives or stays in a particular place.
Example: The residents of westville 
(2) A doctor working at a hospital where he or she is being trained.
(3) Living in a place.
Example: Many retired british people are now resident in spain. 
(4) Living or working in a particular place or institution.
Example: A resident tutor 
(5) Belonging to a particular group of people – used humorously.
Example: Hes our resident expert on computer games. 
(6) Someone who lives permanently in a particular place.
Example: Interest is paid to uk residents without further liability to basic rate tax.
(7) Someone who is staying in a particular hotel.
Example: At present the hotel bar is open to residents only.

(1) A residential part of a town consists of private houses, with no offices or factories.
Example: A quiet residential neighbourhood 
(2) Relating to homes rather than offices or businesses.
Example: Telephone services for residential customers 
(3) If you are on a residential course, you are living in the institution where you are studying.
(4) Residential property consists of private houses where people live, rather than offices or factories.
Example: Opponents claim the development is too near residential areas .

(1) To officially announce that you have decided to leave your job or an organization.
Example: She resigned from the government last week. 
(2) To make yourself accept something that is bad but cannot be changed.
Example: Josh resigned himself to the long walk home. 
(3) To officially leave a job, position etc through your own choice, rather than being told to leave.
Example: The vice-president resigned his post last week.

(1) The ability to become strong, happy, or successful again after a difficult situation or event.
Example: The resilience of youth 
(2) The ability of a substance such as rubber to return to its original shape after it has been pressed or bent.

(1) To stop yourself from having something that you like very much or doing something that you want to do.
Example: I just cant resist chocolate. 
(2) To try to prevent a change from happening, or prevent yourself from being forced to do something.
Example: He resisted pressure to resign. 
(3) To use force to stop something from happening.
Example: Demonstrators violently resisted attempts to remove them from the building. 
(4) To not be changed or harmed by something.
Example: Your ability to resist infection 
(5) To try to prevent something happening or changing.
Example: It resisted a bid by the denver company to acquire a 46% stake.

(1) A refusal to accept new ideas or changes.
Example: Peoples resistance to change 
(2) Fighting against someone who is attacking you.
Example: Rebel gunmen have put up strong resistance. 
(3) The natural ability of a person, animal, or plant to stop diseases or difficult conditions from harming them.
Example: The bodys resistance to infection 
(4) The way in which wind, air, or water can cause a moving object such as a car, plane, or boat to slow down.
(5) The ability of a substance to stop the flow of an electric current through it.
(6) An organization that secretly fights against an enemy that controls their country.
(7) If you follow the path of least resistance, you avoid making difficult decisions and choose the easiest solution to a problem – often used to show disapproval.
Example: Many people dont make changes because theyre following the path of least resistance . 
(8) A refusal to accept change or new ideas, methods etc.
Example: The company faces resistance from middle managers, who fear the changes will put them out of jobs.

(1) Not damaged or affected by something.
Example: An infection thats resistant to antibiotics 
(2) Opposed to something and wanting to prevent it from happening.
Example: Many managers are resistant to change.
(1) To take an examination again, because you failed it or did not do well enough.

(1) To find a satisfactory way of dealing with a problem or difficulty.
Example: The crisis was resolved by negotiations. 
(2) To make a definite decision to do something.
Example: After the divorce she resolved never to marry again. 
(3) To make a formal decision, especially by voting.
Example: The senate resolved to accept the presidents proposals. 
(4) To separate something into its different parts.
Example: Dna samples were extracted and resolved. 
(5) To separate into parts, or to separate something.
Example: This mixture will resolve into two separate compounds. 
(6) To separate into parts, or to separate something.
Example: This mixture will resolve into two separate compounds. 
(7) To gradually change into something else.
Example: The argument resolved itself into an uneasy truce. 
(8) Strong determination to succeed in doing something.
Example: Recent events strengthened her resolve to find out the truth. 
(9) To find a satisfactory way of settling a disagreement, dispute etc.
Example: Most pension disputes will be resolved within a year.
(10) To make an official decision, especially by voting.
Example: The directors have resolved to ask the company to appoint a receiver.

(1) A place where a lot of people go for holidays.
Example: Aspen, a ski resort in colorado 
(2) What you will do if everything else fails.
Example: Drug treatment should only be used as a last resort. 
(3) What you will do first before you try other things.
Example: In the past, your family was the first resort when looking for a job. 
(4) When you must use or depend on something because nothing better is available.
Example: We hope they will be able to resolve the situation without resort to force. 
(5) To do something bad, extreme, or difficult because you cannot think of any other way to deal with a problem.
Example: Officials fear that extremists may resort to violence . 
(6) A place where a lot of people go for holidays.
Example: It is now the countrys most popular beach resort.

(1) Something such as useful land, or minerals such as oil or coal, that exists in a country and can be used to increase its wealth.
Example: Canadas vast mineral resources 
(2) All the money, property, skills etc that you have available to use when you need them.
Example: She had no financial resources . 
(3) Personal qualities, such as courage and determination, that you need to deal with a difficult situation.
Example: He proved that he has considerable inner resources . 
(4) Something such as a book, film, or picture used by teachers or students to provide information.
Example: Resources for learning 
(5) The ability to deal with practical problems.
Example: A man of great resource 
(6) To provide money or other resources for something.
Example: The program wasnt adequately resourced. 
(7) Something such as money, property, skill, labour etc that a company has available.
Example: We have the necessary financial resources to respond to these problems.
(8) Something such as oil, land, or natural energy that exists in a country and can be used to increase its wealth.
Example: Namibia has substantial coal resources and diamond deposits.
(9) To provide money or other resources that are needed to do particular work.
Example: The program wasnt adequately resourced.

(1) A feeling of admiring someone or what they do, especially because of their personal qualities, knowledge, or skills.
Example: I have the greatest respect for janes work. 
(2) The belief that something or someone is important and should not be harmed, treated rudely etc.
Example: Out of respect for the wishes of her family, the affair was not reported in the media. 
(3) Say this before disagreeing with someone when you want to be polite.
Example: With respect, i think youre wrong. 
(4) A careful attitude towards something or someone that could be dangerous.
Example: My fear turned into a respect for the sea. 
(5) Used to say that something is true in one way, in some ways etc.
Example: In many respects the new version is not as good as the old one. 
(6) Polite greetings.
Example: Give my respects to your wife. 
(7) To go to someone’s funeral.
(8) Concerning or in relation to something.
Example: This is especially true in respect of the uk. 
(9) Concerning or in relation to something.
Example: The freedom of a property owner to make a contract with respect to his property 
(10) To admire someone because they have high standards and good qualities such as fairness and honesty.
Example: She respected him for his honesty. 
(11) To be careful not to do anything against someone’s wishes, rights etc.
Example: She said she wanted to leave, and her father respected her wishes . 
(12) To not break a rule or law.
Example: The president is expected to respect the constitution. 
(13) A left-wing political party in england and wales which was started in january 2004. its name is made up of the first letters of the words respect, equality, socialism, peace, environmentalism, and trade unionism. its supporters include the film director ken loach and the playwright harold pinter. one of the party’s most important members is george galloway. the party’s full name is respect – the unity coalition..
(14) In payment for.
Example: Tescos auditors also received 1.2 million in respect of audit work.
(15) About or concerning.
Example: How much time are buyers spending on their purchasing decisions with respect to various products?

(1) To do something as a reaction to something that has been said or done.
Example: Responding to the news, mr watt appealed for calm. 
(2) To say or write something as a reply.
Example: He responded that he didnt want to see anyone. 
(3) To improve as a result of a particular kind of treatment.
Example: She has responded well to treatment. 
(4) To react to something that has happened.
Example: The company responded aggressively by selling market-rate investments.
(5) To reply to a letter, telephone call etc.
Example: Thousands of readers saw the ad and responded.

(1) Someone who answers questions, especially in a survey.
Example: Only 62 percent of respondents said they were satisfied.  62% 
(2) Someone who has to defend their own case in a law court, especially in a divorce case.
(3) Someone who replies to an advertisement or set of questions.
Example: Only 2.7% of the survey respondents said they had plans to buy a home in the next six months.
(4) Someone who defends themselves in a law case.
Example: Without admitting the allegations, the respondents agreed with the courts finding that the firm failed to maintain the minimum capital required.

(1) Something that is done as a reaction to something that has happened or been said.
Example: The publics response to our appeal for help 
(2) Something that is said or written as a reply.
Example: sure, why not? was his response to all of billies suggestions.  :   
(3) Something done as a reaction to something that has happened.
Example: The companys difficulties have touched off widely differing responses among its five largest shareholders.
(4) A reply to a letter, telephone call, advertisement etc.
Example: It ran a series of radio ads and got 10,000 responses from investors.
(5) The time it takes to react to something.
Example: A 24-hour response time on all customer enquiries

(1) A duty to be in charge of someone or something, so that you make decisions and can be blamed if something bad happens.
Example: Kellys promotion means more money and more responsibility. 
(2) Blame for something bad that has happened.
Example: The firm is denying all responsibility . 
(3) Something that you must do as part of your job or duty.
Example: My responsibilities include answering the phone and dealing with customer enquiries. 
(4) Something that you ought to do because it is morally or socially right.
Example: We all have a responsibility to protect the environment. 
(5) A duty to help someone because of your work or position in society.
Example: A doctors first responsibility is to her patients. 
(6) To do something without being told to do it or officially allowed to do it.
(7) When someone is officially in charge of something and has to make decisions about it.
Example: In his new post, he will assume responsibility for all the companys radio and tv operations.
(8) All the things someone is in charge of in a particular job, position etc.
Example: My workload and responsibilities have increased more than my salary.
(9) Blame for something bad that has happened.
Example: As chief executive, i accept responsibility for certain administrative problems.

(1) If someone is responsible for an accident, mistake, crime etc, it is their fault or they can be blamed.
Example: Police believe that the same man is responsible for three other murders in the area. 
(2) Having a duty to be in charge of or to look after someone or something.
Example: Mills is responsible for a budget of over $5 million. 
(3) If something is responsible for a change, problem, event etc, it causes it.
Example: The floods were responsible for over a hundred deaths. 
(4) Sensible and able to make good judgments, so that you can be trusted.
Example: You can leave the children with billy  hes very responsible. 
(5) A job in which the ability to make good judgments and decisions is needed.
(6) If you are responsible to someone, that person is in charge of your work and you must explain what you have done to them.
Example: Cabinet members are directly responsible to the president. 
(7) To be officially in charge of something as part of your job, meaning you must accept the blame if something goes wrong.
Example: Partners are officially responsible for all the firms financial obligations.
(8) If you are responsible to someone in your job, you have to report your actions, progress etc to them.
Example: The computer group manager is responsible to the head of computer development.
(9) A job, position etc in which the ability to make good judgements and decisions is important.
Example: As works manager, i had an interesting and responsible job.

(1) To make something return to its former state or condition.
Example: The government promises to restore the economy to full strength. 
(2) To bring back a positive feeling that a person or a group of people felt before.
Example: Measures aimed at restoring public confidence in the education system 
(3) To repair an old building, piece of furniture, or painting etc so that it is in its original condition.
Example: The church was carefully restored after the war. 
(4) To give back to someone something that was lost or taken from them.
Example: The treaty restored okinawa to japan. 
(5) To bring back a law, tax, right etc.
Example: A campaign to restore the death penalty 
(6) Make someone king, queen, or president again, after a period when they have not been in power.
(7) To make something return to its former level or condition.
Example: The governments first task will be to restore the economy.
(8) To make a situation or feeling exist again.
Example: Without fundamental reforms, the profitability of the banking system will not be restored.
(9) To give something back, especially money that is owed.
Example: The government agreed to restore an estimated $120 million that had been cut from the energy department budget.

(1) To stop someone from doing something, often by using physical force.
Example: I had to restrain her from running out into the street. 
(2) To control your own emotions or behaviour.
Example: Renwick restrained a feeling of annoyance. 
(3) To control or limit something that is increasing too much.
Example: Price rises should restrain consumer spending. 
(4) To control or limit something that is starting to increase.
Example: Tough rules to restrain the creation of monopolies

(1) To limit or control the size, amount, or range of something.
Example: The new law restricts the sale of hand guns. 
(2) To limit someone’s actions or movements.
Example: The cramped living conditions severely restricted the childrens freedom to play. 
(3) To allow yourself to have or do only a particular thing or amount of something.
Example: Im restricting myself to two cigarettes a day. 
(4) To limit or put controls on the amount, size, or range of something.
Example: The bank imposed a ruling, restricting credit increases to 2.5%.

(1) A rule or law that limits or controls what people can do.
Example: Restrictions on immigration 
(2) When you restrict the size, amount, or range of something.
(3) An official rule that limits or controls what people can do or what is allowed to happen.
Example: Construction lending has been badly hit by restrictions on loans.

(1) To start doing something again after stopping or being interrupted.
Example: She hopes to resume work after the baby is born. 
(2) If an activity or process resumes, it starts again after a pause.
Example: Peace talks will resume tomorrow. 
(3) To go back to the seat, place, or position where you were before.
Example: Will the delegates please resume their seats? 
(4) A short account of something such as an article or speech which gives the main points but no details.
Example: A brief rsum of the days events 
(5) A short written account of your education and your previous jobs that you send to an employer when you are looking for a new job.
(6) To start to do something again after a period of rest or an interruption.
Example: Profit-taking resumed as the yen began to lose ground.

(1) The sale of goods in shops to customers, for their own use and not for selling to anyone else.
Example: A manager with twenty years experience in the retail business  20 
(2) To be sold for a particular price in a shop.
Example: The wine retails at 6.95 a bottle.  6.95 
(3) To sell goods in shops.
Example: Their products are retailed all over britain. 
(4) To give other people private information about someone or something.
(5) If you buy or sell something retail, you buy or sell it in a shop.
Example: We only deal with wholesalers  we dont sell any of our goods retail. 
(6) The sale of goods to customers for their own use, rather than to shops etc.
Example: His experience in retail includes managing a number of shopping centres in new zealand.
(7) The selling of goods or services to members of the public, or companies involved in this.
Example: Anyone working in the retail trade will often have to deal with customers who want to exchange or return goods.
(8) A shop etc that is open to members of the public.
Example: These large retail outlets stock a wide range of goods.
(9) Banking or investment services available to members of the public, rather than to businesses or companies.
(10) An individual customer etc, rather than a business or company.
Example: The scheme relates to all new cars sold to retail customers.
(11) To be sold to the public, usually in shops, for a particular price.
Example: The doll will retail for about 36.
(12) To sell goods in small quantities to members of the public, usually in a shop.
Example: The product is not being retailed through the right kind of outlets.
(13) If something is sold retail, it is sold to members of the public, usually in a shop.
Example: We only deal with wholesalers - we dont sell any of our goods retail.

(1) A person or business that sells goods to customers in a shop.
(2) A business that sells goods to members of the public, rather than to shops etc.
Example: A national furniture retailer with 20,000 employees
(3) Someone who owns or runs a shop selling goods to members of the public.

(1) The business of selling goods to customers in shops.
Example: There may be many job losses in retailing.

(1) To keep something or continue to have something.
Example: You have the right to retain possession of the goods. 
(2) To store or keep something inside something else.
Example: A lot of information can be retained in your computer. 
(3) To remember information.
Example: I find it very difficult to retain facts. 
(4) If you retain a lawyer or other specialist, you pay them to work for you now and in the future.
Example: He has retained a lawyer to challenge the courts decision. 
(5) If a company retains workers, it continues to employ them for a long time.
Example: Its increasingly difficult to recruit and retain good staff. 
(6) To keep something or to continue to have it.
Example: A duplicate copy of the invoice will be retained for record purposes.
(7) To continue to employ people after a company has changed ownership, reduced in size etc.
Example: The new company retained all the staff employed at the time of the takeover.
(8) If a company retains a lawyer or other specialist, it pays them to do work for it, now or in the future.
Example: The company will retain an auditing firm for six months to review its business practices.

(1) To do something bad to someone because they have done something bad to you.
Example: The british government retaliated by breaking off diplomatic relations.

(1) To stop working, usually because you have reached a certain age.

(1) If something that you value very much is at stake, you will lose it if a plan or action is not successful.

Example: Im sure thats jesse  id stake my life on it.

(15) To say publicly that you think you have a right to have or own something.
Example: Both countries staked a claim to the islands. 
(16) To watch a place secretly and continuously.

(17) To watch a place secretly and continuously.
Example: Police officers have been staking out the warehouse for weeks.

(1) Bread or cake that is stale is no longer fresh or good to eat.

Example: If you stay in the job for more than ten years, you get stale .

(1) A table or a small shop with an open front, especially outdoors, where goods are sold.

(1) A small piece of paper that you buy and stick onto an envelope or package before posting it.

Example: Television licence stamps

Example: Hes clearly of a very different stamp.

Example: An angry stamp 
(8) To put your foot down onto the ground loudly and with a lot of force.
Example: The audience stamped and shouted.

Example: My mother stamped off down the stairs.  
(10) To put a pattern, sign, or letters on something, using a special tool.
Example: The woman at the desk stamped my passport.

Example: She stitched up the cut and left it to heal.

(1) A supply of a particular type of thing that a shop has available to sell.
Example: We have a huge stock of quality carpets on sale.

Example: The trading of stocks and shares 
(3) The total amount of something that is available to be used in a particular area.
Example: Cod stocks in the north atlantic have dropped radically. 
(4) A supply of something that you keep and can use when you need to.
Example: He keeps a stock of medicines in the cupboard. 
(5) To think carefully about the things that have happened in a situation in order to decide what to do next.
Example: While in hospital, jeremy took stock of his life. 
(6) A liquid made by boiling meat or bones and vegetables, which is used to make soups or to add flavour to other dishes.
Example: Chicken stock 
(7) The part of a gun that you hold or put against your shoulder, usually made of wood.
(8) Farm animals, especially cattle.
(9) A wooden structure in a public place to which criminals were fastened by their feet or hands in the past.
(10) If someone’s stock is high or low, they are very popular or very unpopular.
Example: Simons stock is high in the network news business. 
(11) The jokes, knowledge etc that someone knows or has.
Example: John seems to have an inexhaustible stock of funny stories. 
(12) To belong to a family that in the past lived in scotland, were protestants, were respected etc.
(13) A plant with pink, white, or light purple flowers and a sweet smell.
(14) A thick part of a stem onto which another plant can be added so that the two plants grow together.
(15) A stock company(2).
(16) If a shop stocks a particular product, it keeps a supply of it to sell.
Example: We stock a wide range of kitchen equipment. 
(17) To fill something with a supply of something.
Example: Our refrigerator at college was always stocked with beer. 
(18) To buy a lot of something in order to keep it for when you need to use it later.
Example: I have to stock up on snacks for the party. 
(19) An excuse etc that people often say or use, especially when they cannot think of anything more interesting or original – used to show disapproval.
(20) Something that is available in a shop and does not have to be ordered.
(21) One of the shares into which ownership of a company is divided, or these shares considered together.
Example: The company might issue (= make available and sell ) stock in order to pay down debt.
(22) Different classes of a company’s stock. each class has different characteristics, for example the right to vote at shareholders’ meetings.
Example: The class b stock carries 10 times the votes of the class a common stock.
(23) One of the bonds sold by a government to finance its budget deficit (=the difference between what it gets in taxes and what it spends). government bonds are usually considered to be a very safe form of investment.
(24) A supply of a commodity (=oil, metal, farm product etc) that has been produced and is kept to be used when needed.
Example: Global stocks (= total stocks in the world ) of cocoa amount to 2 million tons, the equivalent of about eight months usage.

Example: If you are going to have a large stock of components you must store them sensibly.
(26) A supply of goods, kept for sale by a shop or other retailer.
Example: Equipment importers had big stocks of last years skis and boots still on their hands.
(27) The houses, flats etc available in a particular place.
Example: The list of discounts offered by housebuilders gets longer as the stock of unsold new homes rises.
(28) An amount of gold, money etc that a country, company etc has available at a particular time.
Example: The us gold stock was down $1 million in november to $11.06 billion.
(29) Farm animals, especially cattle.
Example: He invested in stock, building up a herd of 1000 cattle.
(30) If a shop stocks a particular product, it keeps a supply of it to be sold.
Example: Independent boutiques that sell expensive clothes are stocking less merchandise as their sales drop.
(31) To have a supply of something so that it is ready to be used.
Example: The parts depot in california is well-stocked (= has lots of parts in stock ) .

(1) A large supply of things that is kept ready for use in the future.
Example: A stockpile of nuclear weapons 
(2) To keep adding to a supply of goods, weapons etc that you are keeping ready to use if you need them in the future.
Example: An enormous volume of explosives was stockpiled inside one of the buildings. 
(3) To keep adding to a large supply of goods, weapons etc that are being kept for use or possible use in the future.
Example: The us government began stockpiling oil in response to the oil embargo.
(4) A large supply of goods, weapons etc that are being kept for use in the future, often because they will be difficult to obtain later.
Example: Following poor harvests, stockpiles of grain are expected to fall to their tightest level for 20 years.

(1) A piece of kitchen equipment on which you cook food in pots and pans, and that contains an oven.

(1) Worry that is caused by having to deal with a problem or work too hard over a long period of time.
Example: I couldnt look after him anymore; the strain was too much for me. 
(2) A difficulty or problem that is caused when a person, relationship, organization, or system has too much to do or too many problems to deal with.
Example: The dry summer has further increased the strain on water resources. 
(3) A situation in which something is being pulled or pushed, or is holding weight, and so might break or become damaged.
Example: The strain on the cables supporting the bridge is enormous. 
(4) An injury to a muscle or part of your body that is caused by using it too much.
Example: Long hours working at a computer can cause eye strain.

Example: Different strains of wheat 
(6) A particular quality which people have, especially one that is passed from parents to children.
Example: Theres a strain of madness in his family. 
(7) An amount of a feeling that you can see in the way someone speaks, writes, paints etc.
Example: A strain of bitterness in youngs later work 
(8) The sound of music being played.
Example: We sipped wine to the strains of beethoven. 
(9) To injure a muscle or part of your body by using it too much or making it work too hard.
Example: Ive strained a muscle in my leg. 
(10) To try very hard to do something using all your strength or ability.
Example: She was straining to keep her head above the water. 
(11) To separate solid things from a liquid by pouring the mixture through something with very small holes in it.

(12) To cause difficulties for something by making too much work or too many problems which it cannot deal with easily.
Example: The increased costs will certainly strain our finances.

Example: Buddys huge gut strained against the buttons on his shirt.

(16) To not work too hard or do too much physical activity – often used in an ironic way.

(1) A natural flow of water that moves across the land and is narrower than a river.

(1) To hit or fall against the surface of something.

Example: His jokes didnt strike jack as being very funny. 
(5) If a group of workers strike, they stop working as a protest against something relating to their work, for example how much they are paid, bad working conditions etc.
Example: In many countries, the police are forbidden to strike.

Example: The killer might strike again.

(1) A line of colour, especially one of several lines of colour all close together.

(1) Used to say you think something is true, although you are uncertain about it.
Example: I suppose youre right. 
(2) Used to ask a question in an indirect way, especially if you think the answer will be ‘no’.
Example: I dont suppose you have any idea where my address book is, do you?  , 
(3) Used to ask someone their opinion about something, although you know that it is unlikely that they have any more information about the situation than you do.
Example: Do you suppose this is the exact spot? 
(4) Used when you are annoyed by what someone has just said.
Example: it sounds like things arent going too well for you lately. whats that supposed to mean?     
(5) Used when talking about a possible condition or situation, and then imagining the result.
Example: Look, suppose you lost your job tomorrow, what would you do?  ,  , 
(6) Used to say what someone should or should not do, especially because of rules or what someone in authority has said.
Example: Were supposed to check out of the hotel by 11 o'clock.  11 
(7) To think that something is probably true, based on what you know.
Example: There were many more deaths than was first supposed. 
(8) To expect that something will happen or be true, and to base your plans on it.
Example: The companys plan supposes a steady increase in orders.

(1) To stop people from opposing the government, especially by using force.
Example: The uprising was ruthlessly suppressed. 
(2) If important information or opinions are suppressed, people are prevented from knowing about them, even if they have a right to know.
Example: The police were accused of suppressing evidence. 
(3) To stop yourself from showing your feelings.
Example: Harry could scarcely suppress a smile. 
(4) To prevent something from growing or developing, or from working effectively.
Example: The virus suppresses the bodys immune system. 
(5) To prevent something from developing or making progress.
Example: The recession is suppressing demand for our products.
(6) To deliberately prevent people knowing important information, ideas, opinions etc.
Example: Advertisers use their influence to suppress negative news coverage about their products.

(1) To ride on waves while standing on a special board.
(2) To look quickly through information on the internet for anything that interests you.
(3) The white substance that forms on top of waves as they move towards the shore.
(4) To look quickly at information on the internet or at several different television programmes to find something that interests you.
Example: You can surf 35 home shopping channels and still not find what you want.

(1) The top layer of an area of water or land.
Example: Dead leaves floated on the surface of the water. 
(2) The outside or top layer of something.
Example: The surface of the vase 
(3) The qualities, emotions etc of someone or something that are easy to notice, but which are not the only or not the real qualities, emotions etc.
Example: On the surface, it seems a simple story. 
(4) A flat area on the top of a cupboard, table, desk etc, that you use for cooking or working on.
Example: Keep kitchen surfaces clean and tidy. 
(5) One of the sides of an object.
Example: How many surfaces does a cube have? 
(6) If information, feelings, or problems surface, they become known about or easy to notice.
Example: Rumors about the killings have begun to surface in the press. 
(7) If someone or something surfaces, they suddenly appear somewhere, especially after being gone or hidden for a long time.
Example: Last year toole surfaced again in cuba. 
(8) To rise to the surface of water.
Example: Divers surfacing near the boat 
(9) To get out of bed, especially late.
Example: Joe never surfaces before midday on sunday. 
(10) To put a surface on a road.
(11) Relating to the part of the army, navy etc that travels by land or on the sea, rather than by air or under the sea.
Example: The navys surface forces 
(12) Appearing to be true or real, but not representing what someone really feels or what something is really like.
Example: Beneath the surface calm, she felt very insecure.

(1) To suddenly move very quickly in a particular direction.
Example: The taxi surged forward. 
(2) If a feeling surges or surges up, you begin to feel it very strongly.
Example: She could feel anger surging inside her. 
(3) If a large amount of a liquid, electricity, chemical etc surges, it moves very quickly and suddenly.
Example: A wave surged up towards them. 
(4) To suddenly increase.
Example: Oil prices surged. 
(5) A sudden large increase in a feeling.
Example: A surge of excitement 
(6) A sudden increase in amount or number.
Example: A surge in food costs 
(7) A sudden movement of a lot of people.
Example: A surge of refugees into the country 
(8) A sudden quick movement of a liquid, electricity, chemical etc through something.
Example: A device that protects your computer against electrical surges 
(9) To increase suddenly.
Example: Stock prices surged in early trading.
(10) A sudden increase in something such as demand, profit, price etc.
Example: Nearly two million people applied for shares in a last-minute surge of applications.
(1) A doctor who does operations in a hospital.

(1) To be even better or greater than someone or something else.

(1) To be all around someone or something on every side.

(1) The objects, buildings, natural things etc that are around a person or thing at a particular time.

(1) When the police, army etc watch a person or place carefully because they may be connected with criminal activities.

Example: A surveillance mission

Example: Diane was placed under psychiatric surveillance.

(1) A set of questions that you ask a large number of people in order to find out about their opinions or behaviour.

(2) An examination of an area of land in order to make a map of it.
(3) An examination of a house or other building done especially for someone who wants to buy it.
(4) A general description or report about a particular subject or situation.
Example: A survey of modern english literature

Example: She turned to survey her daughters pale face.

Example: There were many voyages to survey the ocean depths in the nineteenth century. 19

(1) To continue to live after an accident, war, or illness.
Example: Only 12 of the 140 passengers survived. 140  12 
(2) To continue to live normally in spite of many problems.
Example: Im sure she will survive this crisis. 
(3) To manage to live a normal life even though you have very little money.
Example: I dont know how you all manage to survive on jeremys salary. 
(4) To continue to exist after a long time.
Example: A few pages of the original manuscript still survive. 
(5) To continue to be successful.
Example: The car industry cannot survive without government help. 
(6) To live longer than someone else, usually someone closely related to you.
Example: He is survived by his wife sue. 
(7) If a business survives, it manages to continue operating, even though it is in a very difficult situation.
Example: To survive, companies will have to focus on staff development.
(8) If you survive, you continue to live. if you survive someone, you continue to live after they have died.
Example: Provided her husband survived her by 30 days, he would receive the income from her fathers estate.

(1) Likely to suffer from a particular illness or be affected by a particular problem.
Example: Older people are more susceptible to infections. 
(2) A susceptible person is easily influenced or attracted by someone or something.
Example: A lot of tv advertising is aimed at susceptible young children. 
(3) If something is susceptible of an action, that action can be done to it.
Example: Working conditions are susceptible of improvement by legislation.

(1) To think that something is probably true, especially something bad.
Example: I suspected that there was something wrong with the engine. 
(2) To think that something bad has happened or is happening.
Example: The doctors suspected pneumonia. 
(3) To think that someone is probably guilty of a crime.
Example: Who do you suspect? 
(4) To think that something is not honest or true.
Example: I began to suspect his motives in inviting me. 
(5) Someone who is thought to be guilty of a crime.
Example: Two suspects were arrested today in connection with the robbery. 
(6) The people or things that are usually involved in or responsible for a particular activity.
Example: A wine shop stocking all the usual suspects: wines from california, france, australia 
(7) Not likely to be completely honest.
Example: Ive always thought he was a bit of a suspect character. 
(8) Not likely to be completely true.
Example: The two men were convicted on the basis of some highly suspect evidence. 
(9) Likely to have problems and not work well.
Example: The engine sounded a bit suspect. 
(10) Likely to contain a bomb or something illegal or dangerous.
Example: Police were called in to check out a suspect van.

(1) To officially stop something from continuing, especially for a short time.
Example: Sales of the drug will be suspended until more tests are completed. 
(2) To make someone leave their school or job for a short time, especially because they have broken the rules.
Example: The two police officers have been suspended until an enquiry is carried out. 
(3) To attach something to a high place so that it hangs down.

(4) To decide not to make a firm decision or judgment about something until you know more about it.
(5) To try to believe that something is true, for example when you are watching a film or play.
(6) If something is suspended in a liquid or in air, it floats in it without moving.

Example: The company has suspended production at its arkansas plant.
(8) To make someone leave a job, position, or organization for a short time, especially because they have broken the rules.
Example: The firm suspended two senior accountants after allegations of financial mismanagement.

(1) To make something continue to exist or happen for a period of time.
Example: She found it difficult to sustain the childrens interest. 
(2) To suffer damage, an injury, or loss of money.
Example: Two of the firefighters sustained serious injuries. 
(3) If food or drink sustains a person, animal, or plant, it makes them able to continue living.
Example: They gave me barely enough food to sustain me. 
(4) To make someone feel strong and hopeful.
Example: The thought of seeing her again was all that sustained me. 
(5) To hold up the weight of something.
Example: He leant against her so heavily that she could barely sustain his weight. 
(6) To support an idea or argument, or prove that it is right.
Example: This argument is difficult to sustain.

Example: Like other insurance companies, we have sustained heavy losses .
(8) To manage to make something continue to exist over a long period of time.
Example: The dow jones broke above the 2935 level in the early afternoon but was unable to sustain the gains .

(1) Able to continue without causing damage to the environment.

(2) Able to continue for a long time.
Example: The party is promising low inflation and sustainable economic growth. 
(3) Strong enough to continue existing or happening for a long time.
Example: The market wants to see more evidence that price stability is sustainable.

(1) To make food or drink go down your throat and towards your stomach.
Example: He swallowed the last of his coffee and asked for the bill.

Example: Leo swallowed hard and walked into the room. 
(3) To believe a story, explanation etc that is not actually true.
Example: Do they really think we are stupid enough to swallow that?

Example: She swallowed her anger and turned to face him.

(6) If a company or country is swallowed up by a larger one, it becomes part of it and no longer exists on its own.
Example: Hundreds of small companies have been swallowed up by these huge multinationals. 
(7) If a company or country is swallowed up by a larger one, it becomes part of it and no longer exists on its own.
Example: Hundreds of small companies have been swallowed up by these huge multinationals. 
(8) If something is swallowed up, it disappears because something covers it or hides it.
Example: Jane was soon swallowed up in the crowd. 
(9) If an amount of money is swallowed up, you have to spend it to pay for things.
Example: The extra cash was soon swallowed up. 
(10) A small black and white bird that comes to northern countries in the summer.
(11) An action in which you make food or drink go down your throat.
Example: He downed his whisky in one swallow. 
(12) To accept something unpleasant.
Example: Car dealers are sceptical that customers will swallow the price increases .
(13) If an activity swallows a lot of time or money, it takes that length of time or uses that amount of money.
Example: Development of the new models engine will have swallowed at least six years and an estimated 6 billion kronor.

(1) Land that is always very wet or covered with a layer of water.

Example: Huge waves swamped the vessel.

Example: Cheap imports still swamp u.s. sales in electronic appliances.

(1) To give something to someone and get something in return.

Example: Someone had gone into the nursery and swapped all the babies around.

(1) To use rude and offensive language.
